questions.question: Migraine
questions.answer: Migraine is a severe headache with throbbing pain, usually on one side of the head. Treatment includes pain relievers like ibuprofen, rest in a dark quiet room, cold compress on forehead, staying hydrated, and avoiding triggers like stress, lack of sleep, and certain foods. Doctors may prescribe triptans or preventive medications for frequent migraines.

questions.question: Epilepsy
questions.answer: Epilepsy causes repeated seizures due to abnormal brain activity. Treatment involves anti-seizure medications taken daily as prescribed by a neurologist. Lifestyle changes include getting enough sleep, avoiding alcohol, managing stress, and wearing a medical alert bracelet. Most people with epilepsy can control seizures with proper medication.

questions.question: Stroke
questions.answer: Stroke happens when blood supply to part of the brain is blocked or a blood vessel bursts. Immediate hospital treatment is critical. Emergency treatment includes clot-busting drugs within hours of stroke. Recovery involves physical therapy, speech therapy, and medications to prevent another stroke. Prevention includes controlling blood pressure, healthy diet, regular exercise, and avoiding smoking.

questions.question: Anxiety
questions.answer: Anxiety causes excessive worry, nervousness, and fear. Treatment includes therapy like cognitive behavioral therapy, relaxation techniques, deep breathing exercises, regular physical activity, adequate sleep, and limiting caffeine. Medications like SSRIs may be prescribed by doctors for severe cases. Mindfulness and meditation also help manage anxiety symptoms.

questions.question: Depression
questions.answer: Depression causes persistent sadness, loss of interest, and low energy. Treatment includes antidepressant medications, talk therapy or counseling, regular exercise, maintaining sleep schedule, spending time with loved ones, and avoiding alcohol. Combination of medication and therapy works best. Recovery takes time, so patience and consistent treatment are important.

questions.question: Insomnia
questions.answer: Insomnia is difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. Treatment includes maintaining regular sleep schedule, avoiding screens before bed, keeping bedroom dark and cool, limiting caffeine after noon, relaxation exercises before sleep, and avoiding heavy meals at night. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia is very effective. Sleep medications may be used short-term if needed.

questions.question: Vertigo
questions.answer: Vertigo causes spinning sensation and dizziness. Treatment depends on the cause but includes vestibular rehabilitation exercises, Epley maneuver for BPPV, medications like meclizine for symptom relief, staying hydrated, and moving slowly when changing positions. Most cases improve with proper exercises and time. Avoid sudden head movements during episodes.

questions.question: Alzheimer's
questions.answer: Alzheimer's is a brain disease causing memory loss and confusion, mainly in older adults. Treatment includes medications like donepezil to slow progression, mental stimulation through puzzles and reading, physical exercise, social activities, structured daily routine, and caregiver support. While there's no cure, early treatment can help manage symptoms and maintain quality of life longer.

questions.question: Parkinson's
questions.answer: Parkinson's disease causes tremors, stiff muscles, and slow movement. Treatment includes medications like levodopa to increase dopamine levels, physical therapy to improve movement and balance, regular exercise, occupational therapy for daily tasks, and deep brain stimulation surgery in advanced cases. Speech therapy helps with communication difficulties.

questions.question: Concussion
questions.answer: Concussion is a mild brain injury from a blow to the head. Treatment includes complete rest for first 24-48 hours, avoiding screens and bright lights, no sports or physical activities, gradual return to normal activities, staying hydrated, and taking acetaminophen for headache. Most concussions heal within 2 weeks with proper rest.

questions.question: Meningitis
questions.answer: Meningitis is inflammation of brain and spinal cord membranes. It's a medical emergency requiring immediate hospital care. Treatment includes antibiotics for bacterial meningitis, antiviral drugs for viral types, IV fluids, pain relievers, and corticosteroids. Symptoms include severe headache, high fever, stiff neck, and sensitivity to light. Vaccination can prevent some types.

questions.question: ADHD
questions.answer: ADHD causes difficulty paying attention, hyperactivity, and impulsive behavior. Treatment includes stimulant medications like methylphenidate, behavioral therapy, creating structured routines, breaking tasks into smaller steps, regular exercise, adequate sleep, and educational support. Parent training and classroom accommodations help children manage symptoms better.

questions.question: Dementia
questions.answer: Dementia causes memory loss and thinking problems affecting daily life. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms with medications, cognitive stimulation activities, maintaining familiar routines, physical exercise, social engagement, and memory aids like calendars and reminder notes. Creating a safe home environment and caregiver support are essential for quality care.

questions.question: Autism
questions.answer: Autism is a developmental condition affecting communication and behavior. Treatment includes early behavioral therapy like ABA, speech and language therapy, occupational therapy for sensory issues, social skills training, special education programs, and structured routines. Each person with autism is unique, so treatment plans are personalized to individual needs and strengths.

questions.question: Tremor
questions.answer: Tremor is involuntary shaking of hands, arms, or other body parts. Treatment includes medications like beta-blockers or anti-seizure drugs, physical therapy, avoiding caffeine and stress, occupational therapy for daily activities, and deep brain stimulation for severe cases. Essential tremor is the most common type and can be managed with proper treatment.

questions.question: Narcolepsy
questions.answer: Narcolepsy causes excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks. Treatment includes stimulant medications to stay awake, scheduled short naps during the day, regular sleep schedule at night, avoiding heavy meals and alcohol, and medications for cataplexy. Lifestyle adjustments like regular exercise and stress management also help control symptoms.

questions.question: Schizophrenia
questions.answer: Schizophrenia is a mental disorder affecting thinking, emotions, and behavior. Treatment requires antipsychotic medications, regular therapy sessions, family support and education, social skills training, and vocational rehabilitation. Early treatment is important. Most people with schizophrenia can manage symptoms and live fulfilling lives with proper medication and support.

questions.question: Headache
questions.answer: Headache is pain in any part of the head. Treatment includes over-the-counter pain relievers like paracetamol or ibuprofen, rest in a quiet dark room, staying hydrated, applying cold or warm compress, and managing stress. Regular headaches need medical evaluation. Avoiding triggers like skipping meals, lack of sleep, and dehydration helps prevent headaches.

questions.question: Amnesia
questions.answer: Amnesia is memory loss that can be temporary or permanent. Treatment depends on the cause and includes treating underlying medical conditions, cognitive rehabilitation therapy, memory training exercises, using memory aids like journals and reminders, maintaining regular routines, and family support. Some types improve over time while others may be permanent.

questions.question: Neuropathy
questions.answer: Neuropathy is nerve damage causing numbness, tingling, and pain in hands or feet. Treatment includes managing underlying conditions like diabetes, pain medications, physical therapy, proper foot care, avoiding alcohol and smoking, vitamin B supplements, and topical creams. Keeping blood sugar controlled is crucial for diabetic neuropathy.

questions.question: Dyslexia
questions.answer: Dyslexia is a learning disorder affecting reading and writing skills. Treatment includes specialized reading programs, multi-sensory learning techniques, extra time for tests and assignments, audiobooks and text-to-speech tools, one-on-one tutoring, and positive reinforcement. Early intervention and proper support help children with dyslexia succeed in school and life.

questions.question: Seizure
questions.answer: Seizure is sudden uncontrolled electrical activity in the brain. Treatment includes anti-epileptic medications, avoiding triggers like flashing lights and lack of sleep, wearing medical alert ID, ketogenic diet in some cases, and sometimes surgery. During a seizure, protect the person from injury, turn them on their side, and call emergency if it lasts over 5 minutes.

questions.question: Coma
questions.answer: Coma is a state of deep unconsciousness. Treatment requires immediate intensive care in hospital to address the underlying cause, maintain breathing and circulation, prevent complications, monitor brain activity, and provide supportive care. Recovery varies greatly depending on the cause and severity. Family presence and talking to the person may help during recovery.

questions.question: Dizziness
questions.answer: Dizziness is feeling lightheaded or unsteady. Treatment includes staying hydrated, sitting or lying down when dizzy, moving slowly when changing positions, avoiding sudden movements, eating regular meals to maintain blood sugar, and treating underlying conditions. If accompanied by chest pain, severe headache, or vision changes, seek immediate medical care.

questions.question: Paralysis
questions.answer: Paralysis is loss of muscle function in part of the body. Treatment focuses on rehabilitation through physical therapy, occupational therapy, assistive devices like wheelchairs or braces, medications to manage spasticity, preventing complications like pressure sores, and maintaining independence through adaptive equipment. Speech therapy may be needed for facial paralysis.

questions.question: Sciatica
questions.answer: Sciatica is pain radiating from lower back down the leg along the sciatic nerve. Treatment includes rest for a few days, ice or heat therapy, pain relievers, gentle stretching exercises, maintaining good posture, physical therapy, and avoiding prolonged sitting. Most cases improve within weeks. Severe cases may need steroid injections or surgery.

questions.question: Bipolar
questions.answer: Bipolar disorder causes extreme mood swings between highs and lows. Treatment includes mood stabilizer medications like lithium, antipsychotics, therapy to identify triggers, maintaining regular sleep schedule, avoiding alcohol and drugs, stress management, and family support. Consistent medication is important to prevent episodes. Regular monitoring by a psychiatrist is essential.

questions.question: OCD
questions.answer: OCD causes unwanted repetitive thoughts and behaviors. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy with exposure and response prevention, medications like SSRIs, stress management techniques, support groups, regular exercise, and adequate sleep. Treatment helps reduce symptoms and improve quality of life. Family education and support are important for recovery.

questions.question: PTSD
questions.answer: PTSD develops after experiencing traumatic events. Treatment includes trauma-focused therapy like EMDR or CBT, medications for anxiety and depression, support groups with other survivors, stress reduction techniques, regular exercise, avoiding alcohol and drugs, and reconnecting with supportive family and friends. Recovery takes time but most people improve with treatment.

questions.question: Tourette's
questions.answer: Tourette's syndrome causes involuntary movements and sounds called tics. Treatment includes behavioral therapy to manage tics, medications if tics interfere with daily life, stress management, adequate sleep, and avoiding triggers like caffeine. Many children see improvement as they grow older. Education and support help families understand and manage the condition.

questions.question: Delirium
questions.answer: Delirium is sudden confusion and changes in mental state. Treatment requires identifying and treating the underlying cause like infection or medication side effects, ensuring adequate hydration and nutrition, maintaining familiar environment, having family present, avoiding restraints, and managing symptoms. It's common in hospitals but usually reversible with proper treatment.

questions.question: Aphasia
questions.answer: Aphasia is difficulty speaking or understanding language after brain injury. Treatment includes speech and language therapy, practicing communication daily, using gestures and pictures, giving time to communicate, group therapy sessions, and patience from family. Recovery varies but many people regain some language abilities with intensive therapy, especially if started early.

questions.question: Encephalitis
questions.answer: Encephalitis is brain inflammation usually from viral infection. Treatment requires immediate hospitalization with antiviral medications, IV fluids, anti-inflammatory drugs, medications to prevent seizures, breathing support if needed, and rest. Early treatment is crucial. Most people recover but some may have lasting effects like memory problems or fatigue.

questions.question: Hydrocephalus
questions.answer: Hydrocephalus is buildup of fluid in the brain. Treatment usually requires surgery to place a shunt that drains excess fluid, regular monitoring with brain scans, managing symptoms with medications, physical therapy, and follow-up appointments to check shunt function. Early treatment prevents brain damage. Many people with treated hydrocephalus live normal lives.

questions.question: Ataxia
questions.answer: Ataxia causes lack of muscle coordination affecting balance and speech. Treatment includes physical therapy to improve coordination, occupational therapy for daily activities, speech therapy, assistive devices like walkers or canes, treating underlying causes when possible, and adaptive equipment. While some types are progressive, therapy helps maintain independence and quality of life.

questions.question: Neuralgia
questions.answer: Neuralgia is sharp shooting nerve pain. Treatment includes pain medications like anticonvulsants or antidepressants, nerve blocks for severe pain, physical therapy, avoiding triggers, stress management, applying heat or cold, and gentle exercises. Trigeminal neuralgia affects the face while postherpetic neuralgia follows shingles. Different types need specific treatments.

questions.question: Dysarthria
questions.answer: Dysarthria is slurred or slow speech due to weak facial muscles. Treatment includes speech therapy to strengthen muscles and improve clarity, practicing speaking exercises daily, speaking slowly and taking breaks, using communication devices if needed, and treating underlying conditions. Family support and patience during conversations help. Many people improve with consistent therapy.

questions.question: Syncope
questions.answer: Syncope is temporary loss of consciousness or fainting. Treatment includes lying down with legs elevated, staying hydrated, eating regular meals, avoiding prolonged standing, wearing compression stockings, increasing salt intake if recommended, and treating underlying heart or blood pressure problems. If fainting is frequent or unexplained, medical evaluation is needed.

questions.question: Myasthenia
questions.answer: Myasthenia gravis causes muscle weakness that worsens with activity. Treatment includes medications to improve nerve-muscle communication, immunosuppressants, removing thymus gland if needed, avoiding triggers like stress and infection, taking rest breaks, and planning activities for when strength is best. Regular monitoring and medication adjustments help manage symptoms effectively.

questions.question: Dystonia
questions.answer: Dystonia causes involuntary muscle contractions and abnormal postures. Treatment includes botulinum toxin injections to relax affected muscles, oral medications, physical therapy, stress management, adequate sleep, and deep brain stimulation for severe cases. Different types affect different body parts. Treatment plans are individualized based on which muscles are affected.

questions.question: Sleepwalking
questions.answer: Sleepwalking is walking or doing activities while asleep. Treatment includes ensuring safety by locking doors and windows, removing obstacles, maintaining regular sleep schedule, reducing stress, avoiding sleep deprivation, limiting caffeine and alcohol, and sometimes short-term medications. Most children outgrow it. Gently guide the person back to bed without waking them.

questions.question: Hyperactivity
questions.answer: Hyperactivity is excessive movement and restlessness. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, structured routines, regular physical activity to release energy, breaking tasks into small steps, positive reinforcement, adequate sleep, limiting sugar and processed foods, and sometimes medications. Creating calm environments and providing frequent breaks help manage hyperactive behavior.

questions.question: Dysgraphia
questions.answer: Dysgraphia is difficulty with writing and fine motor skills. Treatment includes occupational therapy, using pencil grips and special paper, allowing extra time for writing tasks, using computers or tablets for assignments, breaking writing into smaller steps, and building hand strength through exercises. Early intervention and proper accommodations help children succeed academically.

questions.question: Aphonia
questions.answer: Aphonia is loss of voice. Treatment includes voice rest, staying hydrated, using a humidifier, avoiding whispering which strains vocal cords, treating underlying infections or reflux, speech therapy, and avoiding irritants like smoking. Most cases improve with rest. If voice loss persists beyond two weeks, medical evaluation is necessary.

questions.question: Photophobia
questions.answer: Photophobia is sensitivity to light causing discomfort. Treatment includes wearing sunglasses or tinted lenses, dimming indoor lights, using screen filters on devices, treating underlying conditions like migraines, taking breaks from screens, and adjusting screen brightness. If accompanied by eye pain or vision changes, see an eye doctor immediately.

questions.question: Tinnitus
questions.answer: Tinnitus is ringing or buzzing in the ears. Treatment includes sound therapy with white noise or music, avoiding loud noises, limiting caffeine and alcohol, stress management, hearing aids if hearing loss is present, and cognitive behavioral therapy. While there's no cure, most people learn to manage it with these strategies.

questions.question: Restlessness
questions.answer: Restlessness is inability to stay still or relax. Treatment includes regular exercise, relaxation techniques like deep breathing, limiting caffeine, maintaining sleep schedule, stress management, mindfulness meditation, and addressing underlying anxiety or medical conditions. Creating calming routines and engaging in focused activities help reduce restless feelings.

questions.question: Forgetfulness
questions.answer: Forgetfulness is difficulty remembering things. Treatment includes using memory aids like calendars and reminders, staying mentally active with puzzles and reading, regular physical exercise, adequate sleep, healthy diet, managing stress, staying socially engaged, and treating underlying conditions. If memory loss affects daily life or worsens suddenly, medical evaluation is needed.

questions.question: Confusion
questions.answer: Confusion is difficulty thinking clearly or understanding situations. Treatment depends on the cause but includes treating infections or medication side effects, ensuring proper hydration and nutrition, maintaining familiar environments, having regular routines, adequate sleep, and family support. Sudden confusion requires immediate medical attention as it may indicate serious conditions.

questions.question: Irritability
questions.answer: Irritability is feeling easily annoyed or angry. Treatment includes identifying triggers, stress management techniques, regular exercise, adequate sleep, healthy diet, avoiding alcohol and caffeine, therapy to learn coping skills, and treating underlying conditions like depression or anxiety. Taking breaks and practicing patience help manage irritable feelings.

questions.question: Hallucination
questions.answer: Hallucinations are seeing or hearing things that aren't real. Treatment requires medical evaluation to identify the cause, antipsychotic medications if needed, treating underlying conditions like infections or medication effects, ensuring safety, maintaining regular routines, and family support. Different causes need different treatments, so proper diagnosis is essential.

questions.question: Delusion
questions.answer: Delusions are false beliefs held despite evidence. Treatment includes antipsychotic medications, therapy to challenge distorted thinking, family education and support, maintaining structure and routine, avoiding arguments about the delusions, and treating underlying conditions. Regular monitoring and medication adherence are important for managing symptoms effectively.

questions.question: Agitation
questions.answer: Agitation is feeling upset, anxious, and restless. Treatment includes identifying and removing triggers, creating calm environment, regular routines, gentle exercise, soothing music, deep breathing, medications if severe, and treating underlying causes like pain or infection. In dementia patients, familiar faces and objects help reduce agitation.

questions.question: Numbness
questions.answer: Numbness is loss of feeling in a body part. Treatment depends on the cause but includes treating underlying conditions like diabetes or pinched nerves, physical therapy, avoiding pressure on affected areas, warm baths, vitamin supplements if deficient, and medications for nerve pain. Sudden numbness with weakness needs immediate medical attention.

questions.question: Stuttering
questions.answer: Stuttering is disruption in speech flow with repeated sounds. Treatment includes speech therapy focused on fluency techniques, slowing down speech, breathing exercises, reducing anxiety about speaking, practice in comfortable settings, and support groups. Many children outgrow stuttering. Early intervention improves outcomes. Family patience and support are crucial.

questions.question: Apathy
questions.answer: Apathy is lack of interest, motivation, or emotion. Treatment includes treating underlying depression or other conditions, structured daily activities, social engagement, regular exercise, setting small achievable goals, therapy to identify causes, and family encouragement. Medications may help if related to neurological conditions. Creating routines helps maintain activity levels.

questions.question: Disorientation
questions.answer: Disorientation is confusion about time, place, or identity. Treatment includes treating underlying causes like infections or medication effects, maintaining familiar environment, keeping clocks and calendars visible, regular routines, adequate lighting, family presence, and gentle reminders. Sudden disorientation requires immediate medical evaluation to rule out serious conditions.

questions.question: Lethargy
questions.answer: Lethargy is extreme tiredness and lack of energy. Treatment includes adequate sleep, treating underlying conditions like anemia or thyroid problems, regular exercise, healthy diet, staying hydrated, managing stress, limiting alcohol, and gradual increase in activity. If accompanied by fever or severe symptoms, medical evaluation is needed.

questions.question: Nightmares
questions.answer: Nightmares are disturbing dreams causing fear. Treatment includes maintaining regular sleep schedule, reducing stress before bed, avoiding scary movies or content, relaxation techniques, talking about fears during the day, keeping bedroom comfortable and safe, and limiting caffeine. In children, nightlights and comfort objects help. Frequent nightmares may need therapy.

questions.question: Drowsiness
questions.answer: Drowsiness is feeling sleepy during the day. Treatment includes getting adequate nighttime sleep, maintaining regular sleep schedule, taking short naps if needed, staying active, eating balanced meals, limiting caffeine late in day, treating underlying sleep disorders, and reviewing medications with doctor. Persistent drowsiness needs medical evaluation.

questions.question: Weakness
questions.answer: Weakness is reduced strength in muscles. Treatment includes identifying the cause, physical therapy to build strength, adequate nutrition with protein, treating underlying conditions, gradual exercise program, rest when needed, and assistive devices if necessary. Sudden weakness especially on one side needs immediate medical attention as it may indicate stroke.

questions.question: Spasm
questions.answer: Spasms are sudden involuntary muscle contractions. Treatment includes stretching exercises, applying heat or ice, massage, staying hydrated, ensuring adequate minerals like magnesium and potassium, treating underlying conditions, muscle relaxant medications if severe, and avoiding triggers like overexertion. Regular stretching helps prevent spasms.

questions.question: Fatigue
questions.answer: Fatigue is persistent tiredness not relieved by rest. Treatment includes adequate sleep, treating underlying conditions like anemia or sleep apnea, regular moderate exercise, balanced diet, stress management, pacing activities with rest breaks, staying hydrated, and limiting caffeine and alcohol. Chronic fatigue lasting months needs medical evaluation.

questions.question: Phobia
questions.answer: Phobias are intense irrational fears of specific things. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy with gradual exposure to the feared object, relaxation techniques, breathing exercises, support groups, and sometimes medications for severe anxiety. Most phobias can be successfully treated with therapy. Avoiding the fear only makes it stronger.

questions.question: Clumsiness
questions.answer: Clumsiness is difficulty with coordination and movement. Treatment includes occupational therapy to improve motor skills, physical therapy for balance, vision check, treating underlying neurological conditions, exercises to improve coordination, allowing extra time for tasks, and ensuring safe environment. Some children outgrow clumsiness as motor skills develop.

questions.question: Mutism
questions.answer: Mutism is inability or refusal to speak. Treatment depends on the cause but includes speech therapy, treating underlying psychological conditions, creating comfortable communication environment, alternative communication methods, gradual exposure therapy for selective mutism, family support, and patience. Early intervention improves outcomes, especially in children.

questions.question: Daydreaming
questions.answer: Excessive daydreaming is losing focus and drifting into imagination. Treatment includes setting specific times for focused work, breaking tasks into smaller parts, eliminating distractions, regular breaks, physical activity, mindfulness exercises, adequate sleep, and treating underlying ADHD if present. Some daydreaming is normal and creative.

questions.question: Impulsivity
questions.answer: Impulsivity is acting without thinking about consequences. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, learning to pause before acting, using timers and reminders, structured routines, medications if related to ADHD, stress management, adequate sleep, and practicing decision-making skills. Teaching children to count to ten before acting helps build self-control.

questions.question: Slowness
questions.answer: Slowness in movement or thinking has various causes. Treatment includes identifying underlying conditions like Parkinson's or depression, physical therapy, occupational therapy, allowing extra time for tasks, breaking activities into steps, treating any infections or medication effects, and patience from family. Sudden slowness needs medical evaluation.

questions.question: Stiffness
questions.answer: Stiffness is difficulty moving joints or muscles. Treatment includes gentle stretching, warm baths or heating pads, massage, physical therapy, regular movement throughout the day, anti-inflammatory medications, treating underlying arthritis or neurological conditions, and maintaining good posture. Morning stiffness often improves with gentle activity.

questions.question: Paranoia
questions.answer: Paranoia is unreasonable distrust and suspicion of others. Treatment includes antipsychotic medications, therapy to challenge suspicious thoughts, treating underlying conditions like schizophrenia, creating safe environment, maintaining routines, family support, and avoiding drugs and alcohol. Regular medication and therapy help most people manage symptoms effectively.

questions.question: Hyperventilation
questions.answer: Hyperventilation is breathing too fast causing dizziness. Treatment includes breathing slowly into cupped hands, sitting down and relaxing, practicing calm breathing techniques, treating underlying anxiety, stress management, and reassurance. Most episodes resolve within minutes. Frequent episodes need medical evaluation to rule out other causes.

questions.question: Disorganization
questions.answer: Disorganization is difficulty with planning and organizing. Treatment includes using planners and calendars, creating routines, breaking tasks into steps, using timers and reminders, organizing workspace, treating underlying ADHD, occupational therapy, and learning organizational skills. Visual schedules and checklists help maintain structure and productivity.

questions.question: Rigidity
questions.answer: Rigidity is muscle stiffness and resistance to movement. Treatment includes medications like levodopa for Parkinson's, physical therapy, gentle stretching, warm baths, massage, regular exercise, and treating underlying conditions. Rigidity with fever needs immediate medical attention. Maintaining mobility through regular movement is important.

questions.question: Perseveration
questions.answer: Perseveration is repeating words or actions unnecessarily. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, redirecting to new activities, creating structured routines, treating underlying conditions like autism or brain injury, using visual schedules, and family patience. Gentle interruption and offering alternatives help break the repetitive pattern.

questions.question: Echolalia
questions.answer: Echolalia is repeating others' words or phrases. Treatment includes speech therapy, teaching functional communication, addressing underlying autism or developmental delays, using visual supports, modeling appropriate responses, and family education. Some echolalia is part of normal language development in young children and improves with time.

questions.question: Bruxism
questions.answer: Bruxism is grinding or clenching teeth, usually during sleep. Treatment includes wearing mouth guard at night, stress management, avoiding caffeine and alcohol before bed, jaw exercises, treating sleep disorders, and dental care for damaged teeth. Most people are unaware they grind until told by sleep partner or dentist.

questions.question: Hypersomnolence
questions.answer: Hypersomnolence is excessive daytime sleepiness despite adequate sleep. Treatment includes identifying underlying causes like sleep apnea or narcolepsy, medications to promote wakefulness, scheduled naps, regular sleep schedule, avoiding alcohol and heavy meals, treating depression if present, and maintaining sleep hygiene.

questions.question: Akathisia
questions.answer: Akathisia is inner restlessness with urge to move constantly. Treatment includes adjusting medications causing it, beta-blockers, reducing antipsychotic dose if possible, benzodiazepines for relief, regular exercise, stress reduction, and sometimes switching to different medication. It's often a side effect of antipsychotic medications.

questions.question: Bradykinesia
questions.answer: Bradykinesia is slowness of movement. Treatment includes medications like levodopa for Parkinson's disease, physical therapy, occupational therapy for daily activities, regular exercise, allowing extra time for tasks, using assistive devices, and maintaining mobility. Deep brain stimulation may help in advanced cases.

questions.question: Akinesia
questions.answer: Akinesia is loss of ability to move muscles voluntarily. Treatment includes treating underlying Parkinson's disease with medications, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy if swallowing affected, assistive devices, and sometimes surgery. Regular activity and exercise help maintain remaining mobility and prevent complications.

questions.question: Anhedonia
questions.answer: Anhedonia is inability to feel pleasure from activities once enjoyed. Treatment includes antidepressant medications, therapy to identify and engage in rewarding activities, regular exercise, social activities, treating underlying depression, maintaining routines, adequate sleep, and patience as recovery takes time. Combination of medication and therapy works best.

questions.question: Agoraphobia
questions.answer: Agoraphobia is fear of situations where escape is difficult. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy with gradual exposure to feared situations, medications for anxiety, relaxation techniques, support groups, and family support. Treatment is effective but requires consistent effort. Avoiding feared situations makes the phobia worse.

questions.question: Prosopagnosia
questions.answer: Prosopagnosia is inability to recognize faces. Treatment focuses on compensatory strategies like recognizing people by voice, hairstyle, or clothing, using name tags at gatherings, explaining the condition to others, and developing alternative recognition methods. There's no cure but people adapt well with strategies and understanding from others.

questions.question: Diplopia
questions.answer: Diplopia is seeing double images. Treatment depends on the cause but includes wearing eye patch temporarily, prism glasses, treating underlying conditions like diabetes or thyroid problems, eye muscle exercises, and sometimes surgery. Sudden diplopia with other symptoms needs immediate medical attention.

questions.question: Nystagmus
questions.answer: Nystagmus is involuntary eye movements. Treatment includes treating underlying conditions, corrective lenses, medications to reduce movements, vision therapy, positioning head to minimize movements, and sometimes surgery. While often lifelong, most people adapt well. Treating associated vertigo and dizziness improves quality of life.

questions.question: Anosmia
questions.answer: Anosmia is loss of sense of smell. Treatment includes treating underlying causes like sinus infections, nasal steroids, vitamin A supplements, smell training with strong scents, avoiding smoking, and safety measures like smoke detectors since smoke can't be smelled. Some cases improve over time while others may be permanent.

questions.question: Dysgeusia
questions.answer: Dysgeusia is altered taste perception. Treatment includes treating underlying causes like infections or medication side effects, maintaining good oral hygiene, staying hydrated, using plastic utensils if metallic taste, trying different foods, zinc supplements, and patience as many cases improve over weeks. Adding spices may help enhance taste.

questions.question: Hypersomnia
questions.answer: Hypersomnia is sleeping excessively but still feeling tired. Treatment includes maintaining regular sleep schedule, short scheduled naps, medications to promote wakefulness, treating underlying conditions like depression or sleep apnea, regular exercise, avoiding alcohol, and sleep hygiene. Medical evaluation is important to identify the cause.

questions.question: Catalepsy
questions.answer: Catalepsy is temporary loss of movement and sensation. Treatment depends on the underlying cause but includes medications for associated narcolepsy, avoiding triggers, ensuring safety during episodes, and treating underlying conditions. Episodes usually pass within minutes. Medical evaluation is needed to determine the cause and appropriate treatment.

questions.question: Alexia
questions.answer: Alexia is inability to read despite preserved vision and intelligence. Treatment includes speech and language therapy, using audiobooks and text-to-speech software, occupational therapy, compensatory strategies, treating underlying brain injury if possible, and family support. Recovery varies depending on cause and severity of brain damage.

questions.question: Agnosia
questions.answer: Agnosia is inability to recognize objects, people, or sounds despite normal senses. Treatment includes occupational therapy, speech therapy, using multiple senses together, compensatory strategies, treating underlying brain conditions, creating safe environment, and family support. Different types affect different senses and need specific approaches.

questions.question: Apraxia
questions.answer: Apraxia is difficulty performing learned movements despite normal muscle function. Treatment includes speech therapy for verbal apraxia, occupational therapy for movement apraxia, repetitive practice of tasks, breaking movements into steps, visual cues, and patience. Consistent therapy improves function. Different types need specific treatment approaches.

questions.question: Dyskinesia
questions.answer: Dyskinesia is involuntary jerky movements. Treatment includes adjusting medications causing it, using medications to reduce movements, physical therapy, treating underlying conditions, and sometimes deep brain stimulation. It's often caused by long-term use of certain medications. Working with doctor to optimize medications is important.

questions.question: Hyperalgesia
questions.answer: Hyperalgesia is increased sensitivity to pain. Treatment includes gradually reducing opioid medications if they're the cause, non-opioid pain medications, physical therapy, cognitive behavioral therapy, nerve blocks, treating underlying conditions, and stress management. Careful pain management with various approaches works better than relying on one method.

questions.question: Hypokinesia
questions.answer: Hypokinesia is reduced body movement. Treatment includes medications for underlying Parkinson's disease, physical therapy to maintain mobility, occupational therapy for daily activities, regular exercise program, assistive devices, and treating depression if present. Staying active and mobile helps prevent further decline and maintains independence.

questions.question: Hyperphagia
questions.answer: Hyperphagia is excessive hunger and eating. Treatment includes identifying underlying causes like diabetes or medication effects, structured meal times, high-fiber foods to increase fullness, therapy for emotional eating, medications if caused by certain conditions, and behavioral strategies. Medical evaluation is important to find the cause.

questions.question: Anorexia
questions.answer: Anorexia nervosa is eating disorder with fear of gaining weight. Treatment requires team approach with medical doctor, therapist, and dietitian. Includes therapy to address distorted thinking, gradual weight restoration, treating medical complications, family therapy, and sometimes hospitalization. Recovery is possible but takes time and commitment.

questions.question: Bulimia
questions.answer: Bulimia involves binge eating followed by purging. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy, antidepressant medications, nutritional counseling, treating medical complications, family support, and addressing underlying emotional issues. Regular eating patterns and therapy help break the cycle. Recovery is possible with proper treatment.

questions.question: Hyperthermia
questions.answer: Hyperthermia is dangerously high body temperature. Treatment requires immediate cooling with cool water or ice packs, moving to cool environment, removing excess clothing, drinking cool fluids if conscious, and emergency medical care. Prevention includes staying hydrated, avoiding excessive heat, and taking breaks in cool areas during hot weather.

questions.question: Hypothermia
questions.answer: Hypothermia is dangerously low body temperature. Treatment requires immediate warming with blankets, warm drinks if conscious, moving to warm place, removing wet clothing, skin-to-skin contact, and emergency medical care. Gradual warming is important. Prevention includes dressing warmly, staying dry, and avoiding prolonged cold exposure.

questions.question: Cataplexy
questions.answer: Cataplexy is sudden muscle weakness triggered by emotions like laughing. Treatment includes medications like sodium oxybate, antidepressants, avoiding triggers when possible, regular sleep schedule, and managing narcolepsy if present. Episodes are brief but can cause falls. Sitting down when feeling an episode coming helps prevent injury.

questions.question: Chorea
questions.answer: Chorea causes involuntary jerky dance-like movements. Treatment includes medications to reduce movements, treating underlying conditions like Huntington's disease, physical therapy, occupational therapy for daily activities, safety measures to prevent falls, and family support. Stress and fatigue can worsen symptoms so rest is important.

questions.question: Myoclonus
questions.answer: Myoclonus is sudden brief muscle jerks. Treatment includes medications like valproic acid or levetiracetam, treating underlying causes, avoiding triggers like stress and caffeine, adequate sleep, and physical therapy. Hiccups are a common benign form. Most cases can be managed well with appropriate medication.

questions.question: Athetosis
questions.answer: Athetosis causes slow writhing movements of hands and feet. Treatment includes medications to reduce movements, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy if face is affected, treating underlying cerebral palsy or other conditions, and assistive devices. Movements often worsen with stress and improve with rest.

questions.question: Hemiplegia
questions.answer: Hemiplegia is paralysis of one side of the body. Treatment includes physical therapy to regain movement, occupational therapy for daily activities, speech therapy if needed, assistive devices like braces or wheelchair, treating underlying stroke or injury, and preventing complications. Early intensive rehabilitation improves outcomes.

questions.question: Paraplegia
questions.answer: Paraplegia is paralysis of both legs and lower body. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, wheelchair and mobility aids, preventing pressure sores, bladder and bowel management, treating spinal injury, and psychological support. Rehabilitation helps achieve maximum independence and quality of life.

questions.question: Quadriplegia
questions.answer: Quadriplegia is paralysis of all four limbs. Treatment requires comprehensive care including respiratory support, physical therapy, occupational therapy, assistive technology, preventing complications, bladder and bowel care, and psychological support. Specialized rehabilitation and adaptive equipment help maintain independence and dignity.

questions.question: Neuropathy
questions.answer: Neuropathy is nerve damage causing pain, numbness, and tingling. Treatment includes controlling blood sugar if diabetic, pain medications, vitamin B12 supplements, physical therapy, proper foot care, avoiding alcohol, and treating underlying causes. Topical creams and nerve stimulation may provide relief.

questions.question: Myopathy
questions.answer: Myopathy is muscle disease causing weakness. Treatment depends on the type but includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, medications for inflammation, assistive devices, treating underlying conditions, and genetic counseling for inherited types. Staying active within limits and avoiding overexertion helps maintain muscle function.

questions.question: Encephalopathy
questions.answer: Encephalopathy is altered brain function from various causes. Treatment includes identifying and treating the underlying cause like liver disease or infection, supportive care, medications to reduce brain swelling, proper nutrition, and monitoring. Recovery depends on cause and severity. Some types are reversible with proper treatment.

questions.question: Myelopathy
questions.answer: Myelopathy is spinal cord disorder causing weakness and coordination problems. Treatment includes treating underlying cause, physical therapy, occupational therapy, pain management, surgery if compression is present, and assistive devices. Early treatment can prevent further damage. Regular follow-up is important.

questions.question: Radiculopathy
questions.answer: Radiculopathy is pinched nerve root causing pain radiating down arm or leg. Treatment includes rest initially, physical therapy, pain medications, epidural steroid injections, avoiding activities that worsen pain, and surgery if conservative treatment fails. Most cases improve within weeks with proper treatment.

questions.question: Polyneuropathy
questions.answer: Polyneuropathy affects multiple nerves throughout the body. Treatment includes managing diabetes or other underlying causes, pain medications, physical therapy, vitamin supplements, foot care, avoiding alcohol, and treating infections. Symptoms often start in feet and hands. Early treatment prevents progression.

questions.question: Mononeuropathy
questions.answer: Mononeuropathy affects a single nerve. Treatment includes rest, splinting affected area, physical therapy, treating underlying causes like diabetes, avoiding pressure on the nerve, and sometimes surgery to relieve compression. Carpal tunnel syndrome is a common example. Most cases improve with conservative treatment.

questions.question: Hydrocephalus
questions.answer: Hydrocephalus is excess fluid in brain cavities. Treatment usually requires surgery to place a shunt that drains fluid, regular monitoring, treating infections, and managing symptoms. Early treatment prevents brain damage. Most people with treated hydrocephalus can live normal productive lives.

questions.question: Microcephaly
questions.answer: Microcephaly is small head size due to abnormal brain development. Treatment focuses on early intervention services, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, managing seizures if present, special education, and family support. Severity varies widely. Early therapy optimizes development and function.

questions.question: Macrocephaly
questions.answer: Macrocephaly is larger than normal head size. Treatment depends on the cause and includes monitoring for hydrocephalus, treating underlying conditions, developmental support, and sometimes surgery if causing problems. Many children with macrocephaly develop normally. Regular monitoring is important.

questions.question: Craniosynostosis
questions.answer: Craniosynostosis is premature fusion of skull bones. Treatment usually requires surgery in infancy to allow normal brain growth, reshaping skull, monitoring development, and addressing any associated problems. Early surgery prevents complications and improves appearance. Most children do well after surgery.

questions.question: Subdural
questions.answer: Subdural hematoma is bleeding between brain and skull. Treatment depends on size but includes monitoring with scans, surgery to drain blood if large, treating underlying injury, preventing seizures, and rehabilitation. It can be life-threatening if not treated. Falls and head injuries are common causes.

questions.question: Epidural
questions.answer: Epidural hematoma is bleeding outside brain covering. Treatment requires emergency surgery to remove blood clot, stopping bleeding, monitoring brain pressure, and intensive care. It's a medical emergency from head trauma. Quick treatment is crucial. Most people recover well with prompt surgical treatment.

questions.question: Hematoma
questions.answer: Brain hematoma is collection of blood in the brain. Treatment depends on location and size but includes surgery to remove blood, medications to reduce swelling, monitoring in intensive care, treating underlying cause, and rehabilitation. Can result from trauma or ruptured blood vessels. Immediate treatment is essential.

questions.question: Aneurysm
questions.answer: Brain aneurysm is bulging weak area in blood vessel. Treatment includes surgical clipping or endovascular coiling to prevent rupture, controlling blood pressure, avoiding straining, and regular monitoring. Ruptured aneurysm requires emergency surgery. Unruptured ones may be monitored or treated preventively.

questions.question: Hemorrhage
questions.answer: Brain hemorrhage is bleeding in or around the brain. Treatment requires immediate hospitalization, surgery to stop bleeding if needed, controlling blood pressure, medications to reduce swelling, intensive care monitoring, and rehabilitation. It's a medical emergency. Quick treatment saves lives and reduces disability.

questions.question: Ischemia
questions.answer: Brain ischemia is reduced blood flow to the brain. Treatment includes emergency clot-busting drugs if caught early, blood thinners, controlling blood pressure, treating heart problems, carotid surgery if needed, and lifestyle changes. TIA or mini-stroke is a warning sign requiring immediate medical attention.

questions.question: Infarction
questions.answer: Brain infarction is tissue death from blocked blood flow. Treatment includes emergency stroke care, rehabilitation therapy, preventing another stroke with medications, controlling risk factors, physical therapy, speech therapy, and occupational therapy. Recovery varies but therapy helps regain lost functions.

questions.question: Abscess
questions.answer: Brain abscess is pus collection from infection. Treatment requires antibiotics for several weeks, surgery to drain abscess if large, treating source of infection, medications to prevent seizures, and monitoring with scans. It's serious but treatable. Early treatment prevents complications and improves outcomes.

questions.question: Glioma
questions.answer: Glioma is brain tumor from glial cells. Treatment includes surgery to remove tumor, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, medications to reduce swelling, treating seizures, and supportive care. Treatment plan depends on type, location, and grade. Multidisciplinary team approach provides best care.

questions.question: Meningioma
questions.answer: Meningioma is usually benign tumor of brain membranes. Treatment includes monitoring with scans if small and not causing symptoms, surgery to remove if growing or causing problems, radiation for remaining tumor, and managing symptoms. Most are slow-growing. Surgery is often curative.

questions.question: Astrocytoma
questions.answer: Astrocytoma is brain tumor from star-shaped cells. Treatment includes surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, medications for symptoms, and rehabilitation. Treatment depends on grade and location. Low-grade tumors have better outlook. Supportive care and symptom management improve quality of life.

questions.question: Medulloblastoma
questions.answer: Medulloblastoma is childhood brain tumor in cerebellum. Treatment includes surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, managing side effects, and long-term follow-up. It requires intensive treatment but many children survive with proper care. Rehabilitation helps with coordination and development after treatment.

questions.question: Glioblastoma
questions.answer: Glioblastoma is aggressive brain tumor. Treatment includes surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, medications for swelling and seizures, and supportive care. While challenging to treat, newer therapies offer hope. Focus on quality of life and symptom management is important throughout treatment.

questions.question: Neuroma
questions.answer: Acoustic neuroma is benign tumor on hearing nerve. Treatment includes monitoring with scans if small, surgery to remove, radiation therapy, or observation. Symptoms include hearing loss and balance problems. Treatment choice depends on size, symptoms, age, and health. Many cases can be observed safely.

questions.question: Schwannoma
questions.answer: Schwannoma is benign tumor of nerve sheath. Treatment includes monitoring if small and not causing symptoms, surgery to remove if growing or problematic, and radiation therapy for difficult locations. Most are slow-growing and non-cancerous. Complete removal usually cures the condition.

questions.question: Pituitary
questions.answer: Pituitary tumors affect hormone-producing gland. Treatment includes medications to control hormones, surgery through nose to remove tumor, radiation therapy, and hormone replacement if needed. Symptoms depend on hormones affected. Most are benign. Treatment controls symptoms and hormone levels effectively.

questions.question: Craniopharyngioma
questions.answer: Craniopharyngioma is rare brain tumor near pituitary. Treatment includes surgery to remove tumor, radiation therapy for remaining tumor, hormone replacement therapy, monitoring vision, and managing symptoms. Though benign, location makes complete removal challenging. Long-term follow-up is necessary.

questions.question: Metastasis
questions.answer: Brain metastasis is cancer spread from other body parts. Treatment includes surgery for single tumors, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, steroids to reduce swelling, treating primary cancer, and supportive care. Treatment depends on number and location of tumors and overall health status.

questions.question: Lymphoma
questions.answer: Primary brain lymphoma is rare cancer of immune cells. Treatment includes chemotherapy, radiation therapy, steroids, monitoring for side effects, and supportive care. Treatment is intensive but many patients respond well. Regular follow-up is important to detect recurrence early.

questions.question: Neuritis
questions.answer: Neuritis is nerve inflammation causing pain and weakness. Treatment includes treating underlying cause like infection, pain medications, physical therapy, rest, anti-inflammatory drugs, and avoiding activities that worsen symptoms. Optic neuritis affects vision and needs urgent treatment. Most cases improve with treatment.

questions.question: Myelitis
questions.answer: Myelitis is spinal cord inflammation. Treatment includes steroids to reduce inflammation, treating underlying infection or autoimmune condition, pain management, physical therapy, bladder care, and preventing complications. Transverse myelitis can cause sudden paralysis. Early aggressive treatment improves outcomes.

questions.question: Cerebellitis
questions.answer: Cerebellitis is cerebellum inflammation causing coordination problems. Treatment includes treating underlying viral or bacterial infection, steroids to reduce inflammation, supportive care, physical therapy for balance, and monitoring. Most children recover well. Symptoms include difficulty walking and coordination.

questions.question: Vasculitis
questions.answer: Brain vasculitis is blood vessel inflammation in the brain. Treatment includes high-dose steroids, immunosuppressant medications, treating underlying conditions, preventing strokes, monitoring with imaging, and managing symptoms. It can cause strokes and requires aggressive treatment. Regular follow-up is essential.

questions.question: Thrombosis
questions.answer: Brain thrombosis is blood clot in brain vessels. Treatment includes blood thinners, treating underlying conditions, managing risk factors, monitoring for complications, and sometimes clot removal. Prevention includes controlling blood pressure, diabetes, and cholesterol. Quick treatment prevents permanent damage.

questions.question: Embolism
questions.answer: Brain embolism is traveling clot blocking brain vessel. Treatment includes emergency clot removal or medications, blood thinners, treating heart problems causing clots, preventing another stroke, and rehabilitation. Time is critical. Symptoms are same as stroke requiring immediate medical attention.

questions.question: Ependymoma
questions.answer: Ependymoma is brain or spinal cord tumor. Treatment includes surgery to remove tumor, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, managing hydrocephalus if present, and rehabilitation. More common in children. Treatment depends on location and grade. Regular follow-up monitors for recurrence.

questions.question: Oligodendroglioma
questions.answer: Oligodendroglioma is slow-growing brain tumor. Treatment includes surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy for higher grade tumors, treating seizures, and monitoring. Many patients live for years with proper treatment. Lower grade tumors have better prognosis. Regular scans monitor tumor activity.

questions.question: Ganglioglioma
questions.answer: Ganglioglioma is rare slow-growing brain tumor. Treatment includes surgery which is often curative, treating seizures which are common symptom, and monitoring. Most are benign and occur in children and young adults. Complete removal usually cures. Seizures often improve after surgery.

questions.question: Hemangioblastoma
questions.answer: Hemangioblastoma is rare benign brain or spinal tumor. Treatment includes surgery which is usually curative, managing associated conditions, monitoring for new tumors, and treating symptoms. Can occur with genetic conditions. Complete surgical removal provides excellent outcomes.

questions.question: Craniotomy
questions.answer: Craniotomy is surgery opening the skull. Recovery includes pain management, wound care, gradually increasing activity, watching for infection signs, taking seizure medications if prescribed, avoiding heavy lifting initially, and follow-up appointments. Most people recover well within weeks. Hair grows back over incision.

questions.question: Lobectomy
questions.answer: Brain lobectomy removes part of brain to treat seizures or tumors. Recovery includes rehabilitation therapy, seizure medications, managing temporary weakness or speech problems, wound care, and gradual return to activities. Many seizure patients become seizure-free after surgery. Outcomes depend on which lobe is removed.

questions.question: Hemispherectomy
questions.answer: Hemispherectomy removes or disconnects half of brain for severe seizures. Treatment involves intensive rehabilitation, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, continued seizure medications, and long-term support. Young children adapt remarkably well. Other brain half compensates for removed side.

questions.question: Ventriculostomy
questions.answer: Ventriculostomy drains brain fluid temporarily. Care includes keeping head elevated, monitoring for infection, avoiding pulling on drain, watching for signs of increased pressure or drainage problems, regular dressing changes, and follow-up. Usually temporary until permanent solution is needed.

questions.question: Shunt
questions.answer: Brain shunt drains excess fluid permanently. Care includes recognizing signs of malfunction like headache or vomiting, protecting shunt area from trauma, regular check-ups, knowing when to seek emergency care, and shunt revisions when needed. Most people live normal lives with shunts.

questions.question: Cranioplasty
questions.answer: Cranioplasty replaces skull bone after previous removal. Recovery includes wound care, avoiding trauma to head, gradually resuming activities, pain management, watching for infection, and follow-up appointments. Plate protects brain and improves appearance. Most people recover well within months.

questions.question: Stereotactic
questions.answer: Stereotactic surgery uses 3D imaging for precise brain treatment. Recovery is usually quick with minimal invasiveness, outpatient or short hospital stay, mild discomfort, quick return to activities, and follow-up imaging. Used for biopsies, tumor treatment, and functional procedures. Very precise with minimal damage.

questions.question: Radiosurgery
questions.answer: Radiosurgery treats brain tumors with focused radiation without cutting. Treatment is outpatient, painless, single or few sessions, gradual tumor shrinkage over months, monitoring with scans, and managing temporary swelling if needed. No anesthesia required. Good option when surgery is risky.

questions.question: Thermocoagulation
questions.answer: Thermocoagulation uses heat to destroy abnormal brain tissue. Treatment is minimally invasive, outpatient procedure, local anesthesia, quick recovery, treating trigeminal neuralgia or tumors, and follow-up. Pain relief is often immediate for neuralgia. Risks are minimal compared to open surgery.

questions.question: Biopsy
questions.answer: Brain biopsy removes small tissue sample for diagnosis. Recovery includes rest for a day, minor headache, small incision care, avoiding strenuous activity briefly, and waiting for results. Usually minimally invasive. Necessary to determine tumor type and guide treatment. Low risk procedure.

questions.question: Trephination
questions.answer: Trephination is drilling hole in skull to relieve pressure. Recovery includes wound care, pain management, monitoring for complications, gradual activity increase, and follow-up. Ancient procedure still used in emergencies. Usually part of larger surgical procedure. Creates access for other treatments.

questions.question: Neuromodulation
questions.answer: Neuromodulation uses devices to alter nerve activity. Treatment includes device implantation, programming adjustments, battery replacements, managing expectations, and monitoring effectiveness. Used for pain, movement disorders, and epilepsy. Adjustable and reversible. Can significantly improve quality of life.

questions.question: Hemianopia
questions.answer: Hemianopia is vision loss in half of visual field. Treatment includes vision therapy, compensatory strategies like scanning, treating underlying stroke or tumor, using prisms, occupational therapy for daily activities, and driving evaluation. Brain adapts over time. Rehabilitation helps maximize remaining vision.

questions.question: Scotoma
questions.answer: Scotoma is blind spot in vision. Treatment depends on cause but includes treating underlying conditions, using visual aids, learning to compensate by moving eyes, occupational therapy, and monitoring for changes. Some improve, others are permanent. Brain learns to fill in missing areas.

questions.question: Amblyopia
questions.answer: Amblyopia is lazy eye with poor vision development. Treatment includes patching good eye to strengthen weak eye, vision therapy, corrective glasses, treating underlying causes early, and eye drops in good eye. Most effective when treated before age 7. Early treatment prevents permanent vision loss.

questions.question: Strabismus
questions.answer: Strabismus is misaligned eyes. Treatment includes corrective glasses, patching to strengthen weak eye, vision therapy, eye muscle exercises, and surgery to align eyes. Early treatment prevents lazy eye. Surgery improves alignment and appearance. Treatment improves depth perception and prevents double vision.

questions.question: Ptosis
questions.answer: Ptosis is drooping eyelid. Treatment includes treating underlying causes, surgery to lift eyelid if affecting vision, using glasses with crutch to hold lid up temporarily, and monitoring. Can be congenital or acquired. Surgery is usually successful. Important to treat if blocking vision.

questions.question: Blepharospasm
questions.answer: Blepharospasm is involuntary eyelid spasms. Treatment includes botulinum toxin injections every few months, oral medications, stress management, dark glasses to reduce light sensitivity, and surgery in severe cases. Can be disabling. Botox injections work well for most people.

questions.question: Hemifacial
questions.answer: Hemifacial spasm is involuntary twitching of one side of face. Treatment includes botulinum toxin injections, medications, microvascular decompression surgery for severe cases, stress management, and avoiding triggers. Usually caused by blood vessel pressing on facial nerve. Injections provide temporary relief.

questions.question: Trigeminal
questions.answer: Trigeminal neuralgia causes severe facial pain. Treatment includes medications like carbamazepine, avoiding triggers like wind or touch, surgery or procedures to reduce nerve pressure, radiosurgery, and pain management. Known as suicide disease due to severe pain. Various treatments available when medications fail.

questions.question: Glossopharyngeal
questions.answer: Glossopharyngeal neuralgia causes severe throat and ear pain. Treatment includes medications similar to trigeminal neuralgia, avoiding triggers like swallowing, surgery if medications fail, and nerve blocks. Less common than trigeminal neuralgia. Pain is triggered by swallowing, talking, or coughing.

questions.question: Occipital
questions.answer: Occipital neuralgia causes sharp pain at back of head. Treatment includes nerve blocks, pain medications, physical therapy, avoiding triggers, massage, heat application, and surgery for severe cases. Often triggered by tight muscles. Steroid injections provide temporary but significant relief.

questions.question: Hyperkinesia
questions.answer: Hyperkinesia is excessive involuntary movements. Treatment includes treating underlying conditions, medications to reduce movements, physical therapy, occupational therapy, avoiding triggers like stress, adequate rest, and sometimes surgery. Includes various movement disorders. Treatment depends on specific type.

questions.question: Hypokinesia
questions.answer: Hypokinesia is decreased movement. Treatment includes medications to improve movement, physical therapy, occupational therapy, regular exercise, treating Parkinson's or other causes, assistive devices, and maintaining mobility. Staying active prevents further decline. Treatment improves quality of life.

questions.question: Ballism
questions.answer: Ballism is violent flinging movements of limbs. Treatment includes medications to suppress movements, treating underlying stroke or other causes, protecting from injury, physical therapy when movements improve, and managing symptoms. Usually affects one side. Often improves over time with treatment.

questions.question: Tics
questions.answer: Tics are repetitive involuntary movements or sounds. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, medications if interfering with life, stress management, adequate sleep, avoiding caffeine, and education. Many children outgrow tics. Treatment focuses on most bothersome tics. Suppressing tics causes discomfort.

questions.question: Myokymia
questions.answer: Myokymia is eyelid twitching. Treatment includes reducing stress, getting adequate sleep, limiting caffeine, taking breaks from screens, eye drops if eyes are dry, and rarely medications. Usually benign and temporary. Persistent twitching needs evaluation. Most cases resolve on their own.

questions.question: Fasciculation
questions.answer: Fasciculations are muscle twitches. Treatment includes treating underlying causes, ensuring adequate minerals and hydration, reducing stress, adequate sleep, limiting caffeine, and medications if severe. Usually benign. Widespread persistent fasciculations need medical evaluation to rule out serious conditions.

questions.question: Cramp
questions.answer: Muscle cramps are sudden painful contractions. Treatment includes stretching the muscle, massage, heat or ice application, staying hydrated, adequate minerals especially magnesium and potassium, proper warm-up before exercise, and medications for frequent cramps. Usually resolve within minutes.

questions.question: Contracture
questions.answer: Contracture is permanent muscle shortening limiting movement. Treatment includes physical therapy with stretching, splinting, occupational therapy, surgery to release tight muscles, preventing further tightening, and maintaining range of motion. Prevention through movement is easier than treatment. Early intervention important.

questions.question: Spasticity
questions.answer: Spasticity is increased muscle tone causing stiffness. Treatment includes physical therapy with stretching, oral muscle relaxants, botulinum toxin injections, baclofen pump for severe cases, treating underlying stroke or injury, and maintaining flexibility. Interferes with movement and function. Various treatments available.

questions.question: Flaccidity
questions.answer: Flaccidity is decreased muscle tone causing weakness. Treatment includes treating underlying nerve damage, physical therapy to strengthen muscles, occupational therapy for adaptations, bracing to support weak limbs, preventing complications, and maintaining function. Opposite of spasticity. Requires different approach.

questions.question: Hypotonia
questions.answer: Hypotonia is low muscle tone causing floppiness. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, treating underlying conditions, nutritional support, developmental interventions, and family education. Common in infants. Many children improve with therapy. Early intervention optimizes development.

questions.question: Hypertonia
questions.answer: Hypertonia is increased muscle tone and resistance. Treatment includes physical therapy, medications to relax muscles, stretching exercises, treating underlying cerebral palsy or injury, orthotics, and sometimes surgery. Affects movement and function. Regular therapy maintains flexibility and prevents contractures.

questions.question: Clonus
questions.answer: Clonus is rhythmic muscle contractions. Treatment includes treating underlying spinal cord or brain injury, medications to reduce spasticity, physical therapy, stretching, and managing triggers. Indicates upper motor neuron problem. Usually accompanies spasticity. Treatment targets underlying condition.

questions.question: Hyperreflexia
questions.answer: Hyperreflexia is overactive reflexes. Treatment includes treating underlying conditions like spinal cord injury, medications to reduce spasticity, physical therapy, monitoring for autonomic dysreflexia, and managing triggers. Can indicate nervous system damage. Monitoring important to prevent complications.

questions.question: Hyporeflexia
questions.answer: Hyporeflexia is decreased reflexes. Treatment includes treating underlying neuropathy or muscle disorders, physical therapy, vitamin supplements if deficient, managing diabetes or other causes, and monitoring progression. Indicates peripheral nerve or muscle problem. Treatment focuses on underlying cause.

questions.question: Areflexia
questions.answer: Areflexia is absent reflexes. Treatment includes treating underlying nerve damage, managing associated weakness, physical therapy, occupational therapy, assistive devices, preventing complications, and monitoring. Indicates significant nerve problem. May be part of larger neurological condition requiring comprehensive care.

questions.question: Hyperesthesia
questions.answer: Hyperesthesia is increased sensitivity to touch. Treatment includes treating underlying nerve damage, pain medications, desensitization therapy, avoiding triggers, protective clothing, and managing symptoms. Simple touch causes pain. Neuropathic pain medications help. Occupational therapy teaches coping strategies.

questions.question: Hypoesthesia
questions.answer: Hypoesthesia is decreased sensation. Treatment includes treating underlying neuropathy, protecting affected areas from injury, proper footwear if feet affected, regular skin checks, physical therapy, and managing causes. Loss of protective sensation increases injury risk. Regular inspection prevents unnoticed injuries.

questions.question: Anesthesia
questions.answer: Anesthesia is complete loss of sensation. Treatment includes treating underlying nerve damage, protecting affected areas, physical therapy, occupational therapy, assistive devices, preventing injuries, and monitoring. Complete numbness increases injury risk. Careful attention needed to prevent unnoticed damage.

questions.question: Paresthesia
questions.answer: Paresthesia is tingling or pins and needles sensation. Treatment includes treating underlying causes like pinched nerves, vitamin B12 supplements if deficient, physical therapy, changing positions frequently, treating diabetes, and medications for neuropathic pain. Usually temporary. Persistent symptoms need evaluation.

questions.question: Dysesthesia
questions.answer: Dysesthesia is unpleasant abnormal sensation. Treatment includes medications for neuropathic pain, treating underlying nerve damage, physical therapy, desensitization techniques, avoiding triggers, and symptom management. Touch feels burning or painful. Nerve pain medications usually help. Can be very distressing.

questions.question: Allodynia
questions.answer: Allodynia is pain from normally painless stimuli. Treatment includes medications for nerve pain, treating underlying conditions, desensitization therapy, avoiding triggers, gentle touch therapy, and pain management. Light touch causes pain. Challenging to treat. Combination of approaches works best.

questions.question: Analgesia
questions.answer: Analgesia is inability to feel pain. Treatment focuses on preventing injuries since pain doesn't warn of danger, regular body checks, protective equipment, teaching safety, treating underlying conditions, and psychological support. Dangerous condition. Protective sensation lost. Careful monitoring essential.

questions.question: Thermoesthesia
questions.answer: Abnormal temperature sensation needs treatment of underlying nerve damage, protecting from burns and frostbite, checking water temperature before bathing, careful cooking, treating neuropathy, and regular monitoring. Loss of temperature sensation is dangerous. Prevention of injuries crucial.

questions.question: Proprioception
questions.answer: Loss of proprioception means not knowing body position. Treatment includes physical therapy with balance exercises, occupational therapy, visual compensation strategies, assistive devices, treating underlying nerve or brain problems, and safety measures. Walking becomes difficult. Visual feedback helps compensate.

questions.question: Kinesthesia
questions.answer: Loss of kinesthesia affects movement awareness. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, visual compensation, treating underlying conditions, assistive devices, and safety adaptations. Similar to proprioception loss. Rehabilitation focuses on using other senses to guide movement.

questions.question: Stereognosis
questions.answer: Loss of stereognosis means unable to identify objects by touch. Treatment includes occupational therapy, sensory retraining, using vision to compensate, treating underlying nerve damage, practicing object recognition, and adaptive strategies. Need to look at objects. Retraining can help some recover.

questions.question: Graphesthesia
questions.answer: Loss of graphesthesia means unable to recognize writing on skin. Treatment includes sensory retraining, occupational therapy, treating underlying nerve problems, and using alternative communication. Less disabling than other sensory losses. Part of broader sensory evaluation. May improve with nerve recovery.

questions.question: Hemianesthesia
questions.answer: Hemianesthesia is numbness on one side of body. Treatment includes treating underlying stroke or brain lesion, protecting affected side from injury, physical therapy, occupational therapy, sensory retraining, and preventing complications. Usually from brain damage. Rehabilitation helps adapt to sensation loss.

questions.question: Dissociation
questions.answer: Sensory dissociation means losing some sensations but keeping others. Treatment includes treating underlying spinal cord problems, protecting from missed dangers, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and monitoring. Can feel touch but not temperature or vice versa. Indicates specific neurological damage.

questions.question: Anosognosia
questions.answer: Anosognosia is lack of awareness of one's own disability. Treatment includes gentle education, occupational therapy, safety measures, treating underlying stroke or dementia, family support, and supervised care. Patient doesn't recognize their problems. Makes treatment challenging. Supervision needed for safety.

questions.question: Neglect
questions.answer: Spatial neglect is ignoring one side of space. Treatment includes visual scanning therapy, occupational therapy, prism glasses, treating underlying stroke, reminders to check neglected side, and adaptive strategies. Usually affects left side after right brain damage. Rehabilitation improves awareness.

questions.question: Extinction
questions.answer: Sensory extinction is ignoring stimuli on one side when both sides stimulated. Treatment includes sensory retraining, occupational therapy, treating underlying brain injury, attention exercises, and using neglected side. Related to spatial neglect. Brain favors one side. Therapy improves bilateral awareness.

questions.question: Astereognosis
questions.answer: Astereognosis is inability to identify objects by touch without seeing them. Treatment includes sensory retraining, occupational therapy, treating underlying parietal lobe damage, using vision to compensate, and practicing object recognition. Brain can't process tactile information. Visual compensation helps.

questions.question: Acalculia
questions.answer: Acalculia is difficulty with math and numbers. Treatment includes cognitive therapy, occupational therapy for practical math skills, using calculators and technology, treating underlying brain injury, and adaptive strategies for daily tasks. Reading and writing may be intact. Calculator use helps independence.

questions.question: Agraphia
questions.answer: Agraphia is difficulty writing. Treatment includes occupational therapy, speech therapy, using computers or voice-to-text, treating underlying stroke or injury, practicing writing, and alternative communication methods. Speaking may be normal. Technology provides good alternatives for communication.

questions.question: Abulia
questions.answer: Abulia is lack of motivation and willpower. Treatment includes treating underlying frontal lobe damage or depression, structured routines, medications, therapy, family encouragement, and setting small achievable goals. Between normal and complete apathy. Requires external structure and motivation.

questions.question: Akinetic
questions.answer: Akinetic mutism is inability to move or speak despite being awake. Treatment requires treating underlying brain damage, supportive care, physical therapy as recovery begins, family presence, and patience. Eyes may track but no other response. Some patients gradually improve with time.

questions.question: Catatonia
questions.answer: Catatonia causes immobility, mutism, and unusual postures.
