Treatment includes benzodiazepines which often work quickly, electroconvulsive therapy for severe cases, treating underlying psychiatric conditions, medical support, and monitoring. Medical emergency if severe. Usually responds well to treatment.

questions.question: Stupor
questions.answer: Stupor is near-unconsciousness with minimal responsiveness. Treatment requires identifying and treating underlying cause like infection or metabolic problems, hospitalization, supportive care, monitoring, and preventing complications. Serious condition needing urgent medical attention. Many causes require different treatments.

questions.question: Obtundation
questions.answer: Obtundation is decreased alertness and awareness. Treatment includes treating underlying causes, hospitalization, monitoring vital signs, supportive care, and preventing complications. Between normal consciousness and stupor. Requires immediate medical evaluation. Many potential causes need investigation.

questions.question: Somnolence
questions.answer: Somnolence is extreme sleepiness and drowsiness. Treatment includes identifying underlying causes like medications or medical conditions, adjusting medications, treating sleep disorders, maintaining sleep hygiene, and monitoring. Different from normal tiredness. Interferes with daily function.

questions.question: Vigilance
questions.answer: Loss of vigilance means difficulty maintaining attention. Treatment includes treating underlying conditions like ADHD or brain injury, cognitive therapy, strategies to maintain focus, adequate sleep, reducing distractions, and taking regular breaks. Affects safety in tasks requiring sustained attention.

questions.question: Perseveration
questions.answer: Perseveration is getting stuck on thoughts or actions. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, redirecting to new activities, treating underlying frontal lobe damage or autism, structured routines, and family patience. Repeating same response inappropriately. Gentle redirection helps break pattern.

questions.question: Confabulation
questions.answer: Confabulation is making up stories to fill memory gaps without lying. Treatment includes treating underlying Korsakoff syndrome or dementia, gentle correction, structured environment, memory aids, avoiding confrontation, and family education. Patient believes false memories are true. Not intentional lying.

questions.question: Reduplication
questions.answer: Reduplication syndrome believes places or people are duplicated. Treatment includes treating underlying brain injury, antipsychotic medications if distressing, reality orientation, family support, and patience. Strange but harmless delusion. Often improves as brain heals. Gentle correction doesn't usually help.

questions.question: Capgras
questions.answer: Capgras syndrome believes loved ones are replaced by imposters. Treatment includes antipsychotic medications, treating underlying dementia or psychiatric condition, family education, maintaining routines, avoiding arguments, and patience. Distressing for families. Recognition intact but emotional connection lost.

questions.question: Fregoli
questions.answer: Fregoli syndrome believes strangers are familiar people in disguise. Treatment includes antipsychotic medications, treating underlying psychiatric conditions, therapy, family support, and maintaining safe environment. Less common than Capgras. Part of misidentification syndromes. Medications usually help.

questions.question: Cotard
questions.answer: Cotard syndrome believes one is dead or doesn't exist. Treatment includes antidepressants, antipsychotics, electroconvulsive therapy, treating underlying severe depression, hospitalization for safety, and supportive care. Rare but serious. Associated with severe depression. Usually responds to treatment.

questions.question: Kluver-Bucy
questions.answer: Kluver-Bucy syndrome causes placidity, oral exploration, and hypersexuality. Treatment includes treating underlying brain damage, behavioral management, environmental safety, medications for specific symptoms, and supervision. From temporal lobe damage. Requires constant supervision. Behavior management is main approach.

questions.question: Gerstmann
questions.answer: Gerstmann syndrome causes difficulty with math, writing, finger recognition, and left-right confusion. Treatment includes occupational therapy, cognitive therapy, treating underlying parietal lobe damage, compensatory strategies, and using aids. From specific brain area damage. Rehabilitation helps adaptation.

questions.question: Anton
questions.answer: Anton syndrome is cortical blindness with denial of blindness. Treatment includes treating underlying occipital lobe damage, reality orientation, safety measures, occupational therapy, and family education. Patient confabulates about what they see. Awareness may improve with time.

questions.question: Balint
questions.answer: Balint syndrome causes inability to see multiple objects and guide hand movements visually. Treatment includes treating underlying bilateral parietal damage, occupational therapy, simplifying environment, adaptive strategies, and family support. Rare syndrome. Can see parts but not whole scene.

questions.question: Korsakoff
questions.answer: Korsakoff syndrome causes severe memory problems from alcohol and vitamin deficiency. Treatment includes high-dose thiamine supplements, stopping alcohol, treating malnutrition, structured environment, memory aids, and long-term support. Often preventable with proper nutrition. Memory rarely fully recovers.

questions.question: Wernicke
questions.answer: Wernicke encephalopathy is medical emergency from thiamine deficiency. Treatment requires immediate high-dose thiamine IV, hospitalization, treating alcohol withdrawal, nutritional support, and monitoring. Causes confusion, eye problems, and coordination issues. Urgent treatment prevents permanent Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.question: Marchiafava
questions.answer: Marchiafava-Bignami disease damages brain connections from chronic alcoholism. Treatment includes thiamine and B vitamins, stopping alcohol, nutritional support, treating symptoms, and supportive care. Rare condition. Variable outcomes. Prevention through avoiding alcohol and proper nutrition.

questions.question: Leigh
questions.answer: Leigh syndrome is genetic progressive brain disease. Treatment includes managing symptoms, vitamins and supplements, treating complications, physical therapy, nutritional support, and family support. No cure. Supportive care improves quality of life. Genetic counseling for families.

questions.question: Canavan
questions.answer: Canavan disease is genetic white matter disease. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms, physical therapy, occupational therapy, nutritional support, treating seizures, and family support. No cure. Progressive condition. Gene therapy research ongoing. Genetic counseling important.

questions.question: Krabbe
questions.answer: Krabbe disease destroys myelin in nervous system. Treatment includes stem cell transplant if done early, managing symptoms, physical therapy, nutritional support, and family support. Genetic condition. Early treatment crucial. Without treatment, rapidly progressive. Newborn screening helps early detection.

questions.question: Tay-Sachs
questions.answer: Tay-Sachs disease is genetic enzyme deficiency affecting brain. Treatment focuses on supportive care, managing symptoms, physical therapy, nutritional support, and family support. No cure. Infantile form is fatal. Adult-onset form milder. Genetic screening and counseling available.

questions.question: Niemann-Pick
questions.answer: Niemann-Pick disease causes harmful substances in brain and organs. Treatment includes managing symptoms, enzyme replacement for some types, bone marrow transplant, supportive care, and family support. Several types with different severity. Some treatments available for specific types.

questions.question: Gaucher
questions.answer: Gaucher disease affects multiple organs including brain in some types. Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy, substrate reduction therapy, managing symptoms, monitoring organs, and supportive care. Type 1 most common and treatable. Brain involvement in types 2 and 3.

questions.question: Fabry
questions.answer: Fabry disease affects multiple organs including strokes. Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy, pain management, preventing strokes, treating heart and kidney problems, and regular monitoring. Genetic condition. Early treatment prevents complications. Both males and females can be affected.

questions.question: Pompe
questions.answer: Pompe disease affects muscles and breathing. Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy, physical therapy, respiratory support, nutritional support, and cardiac monitoring. Genetic condition. Early treatment improves outcomes. Infantile form more severe than late-onset form.

questions.question: Huntington
questions.answer: Huntington disease causes progressive movement and cognitive problems. Treatment includes medications for movements and mood, physical therapy, speech therapy, occupational therapy, nutritional support, and family support. Genetic condition. No cure. Supportive care improves quality of life.

questions.question: Friedreich
questions.answer: Friedreich ataxia causes progressive coordination problems and heart issues. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, assistive devices, treating heart problems, monitoring, and supportive care. Genetic condition. Progressive but life expectancy improving with cardiac care.

questions.question: Charcot-Marie
questions.answer: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease causes progressive nerve damage. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, braces and orthotics, pain management, surgery for foot deformities, and genetic counseling. Most common inherited neuropathy. Usually slowly progressive. Most people remain mobile.

questions.question: Guillain-Barre
questions.answer: Guillain-Barre syndrome causes rapid progressive weakness. Treatment includes hospitalization, immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis, respiratory support if needed, physical therapy, and monitoring. Often follows infection. Most people recover but takes months. Can be life-threatening.

questions.question: Miller-Fisher
questions.answer: Miller-Fisher syndrome causes eye muscle weakness, coordination problems, and reflex loss. Treatment includes immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis, hospitalization, supportive care, and monitoring. Variant of Guillain-Barre. Usually good recovery. Less severe than typical Guillain-Barre.

questions.question: Myasthenia
questions.answer: Myasthenia gravis causes muscle weakness that worsens with use. Treatment includes medications to improve nerve-muscle communication, immunosuppressants, thymectomy, plasmapheresis for crises, avoiding triggers, and regular monitoring. Autoimmune condition. Usually manageable with treatment.

questions.question: Lambert-Eaton
questions.answer: Lambert-Eaton syndrome causes muscle weakness that improves with use. Treatment includes treating underlying cancer if present, medications to improve nerve-muscle communication, immunosuppressants, physical therapy, and monitoring. Often associated with lung cancer. Different pattern than myasthenia gravis.

questions.question: Botulism
questions.answer: Botulism causes paralysis from bacterial toxin. Treatment requires hospitalization, antitoxin given early, respiratory support, tube feeding, wound care for wound botulism, and supportive care. Medical emergency. Prevention includes proper food handling. Recovery takes weeks to months.

questions.question: Tetanus
questions.answer: Tetanus causes severe muscle spasms from bacterial toxin. Treatment requires hospitalization, antitoxin, muscle relaxants, wound cleaning, respiratory support, quiet environment, and supportive care. Medical emergency. Preventable with vaccination. Spasms can be life-threatening.

questions.question: Rabies
questions.answer: Rabies is fatal viral brain infection from animal bites. Treatment before symptoms includes post-exposure vaccination series which is effective. After symptoms, only supportive care available. Almost always fatal once symptomatic. Prevention includes avoiding animal bites and vaccination.

questions.question: Encephalitis
questions.answer: Encephalitis is brain inflammation usually from viruses. Treatment includes hospitalization, antiviral medications, steroids, treating seizures, supportive care, and rehabilitation. Can be serious. Early treatment important. Recovery varies from complete to lasting effects.

questions.question: Meningitis
questions.answer: Meningitis is membrane inflammation around brain and spinal cord. Treatment requires immediate hospitalization, antibiotics for bacterial type, antiviral for some viral types, steroids, supportive care, and monitoring. Medical emergency. Vaccination prevents some types.

questions.question: Neurosyphilis
questions.answer: Neurosyphilis is syphilis infection affecting nervous system. Treatment includes high-dose penicillin IV for several weeks, monitoring spinal fluid, treating symptoms, and follow-up testing. Preventable and curable if caught early. Can cause dementia and paralysis if untreated.

questions.question: Neurocysticercosis
questions.answer: Neurocysticercosis is tapeworm larvae in brain causing seizures. Treatment includes anti-parasitic medications, steroids to reduce inflammation, anti-seizure medications, sometimes surgery, and monitoring. Most common parasitic brain infection worldwide. Prevention through proper hygiene and food safety.

questions.question: Toxoplasmosis
questions.answer: Brain toxoplasmosis is parasitic infection common in AIDS patients. Treatment includes anti-parasitic medications for several weeks, treating HIV, preventing reinfection, and monitoring. Can cause brain lesions and seizures. Preventable in pregnancy and immunocompromised through avoiding raw meat.

questions.question: Cryptococcosis
questions.answer: Brain cryptococcosis is fungal infection in immunocompromised patients. Treatment includes antifungal medications for months, treating HIV or other immune problems, managing increased pressure, and monitoring. Can be fatal if untreated. Common in AIDS patients.

questions.question: Aspergillosis
questions.answer: Brain aspergillosis is fungal infection in immunocompromised patients. Treatment includes antifungal medications, treating underlying immune problem, sometimes surgery, and supportive care. Serious infection with poor outcomes. Prevention includes avoiding mold exposure in high-risk patients.

questions.question: Prion
questions.answer: Prion diseases like CJD cause rapid progressive dementia. No effective treatment exists. Supportive care includes managing symptoms, ensuring comfort, family support, and monitoring. Always fatal. Different from other infections. Extremely rare. Caused by abnormal proteins.

questions.question: Creutzfeldt-Jakob
questions.answer: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease causes rapid dementia and movement problems. No cure exists. Treatment focuses on comfort care, managing symptoms, family support, and dignity. Rapidly progressive. Fatal within year. Most cases sporadic. Very rare. Different from Alzheimer's.

questions.question: Leukodystrophy
questions.answer: Leukodystrophies are genetic white matter diseases. Treatment includes managing symptoms, physical therapy, occupational therapy, nutritional support, treating complications, and family support. Many types exist. Some have specific treatments. Supportive care improves quality of life.

questions.question: Adrenoleukodystrophy
questions.answer: Adrenoleukodystrophy affects brain white matter and adrenal glands. Treatment includes stem cell transplant if caught early, Lorenzo's oil, hormone replacement, managing symptoms, and supportive care. Genetic condition. Early detection through newborn screening helps. Treatment prevents progression if early.

questions.question: Metachromatic
questions.answer: Metachromatic leukodystrophy destroys white matter. Treatment includes stem cell transplant if early, enzyme replacement therapy in trials, managing symptoms, physical therapy, and supportive care. Genetic condition. Earlier treatment better outcomes. Several forms with different ages of onset.

questions.question: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher
questions.answer: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease affects myelin development. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, treating seizures, and family support. Genetic condition affecting mainly males. Spectrum of severity. No cure but supportive care helps.

questions.question: Alexander
questions.answer: Alexander disease causes abnormal white matter and developmental delays. Treatment includes managing symptoms, physical therapy, occupational therapy, treating seizures, nutritional support, and family support. Genetic condition. Infantile form most severe. Adult form milder. No cure.

questions.question: Refsum
questions.answer: Refsum disease causes nerve problems and vision loss from fat buildup. Treatment includes strict dietary restriction of phytanic acid, plasmapheresis, monitoring, and supportive care. Genetic condition. Dietary treatment prevents progression. Early treatment preserves function.

questions.question: Spinocerebellar
questions.answer: Spinocerebellar ataxias cause progressive coordination problems. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, assistive devices, treating symptoms, and family support. Many genetic types exist. No cure. Supportive care maintains function and quality of life.

questions.question: Ataxia-Telangiectasia
questions.answer: Ataxia-telangiectasia causes coordination problems, immune deficiency, and cancer risk. Treatment includes physical therapy, immunoglobulin for infections, cancer screening, avoiding radiation, and supportive care. Genetic condition. Multisystem disease. Requires coordinated care from multiple specialists.

questions.question: Rett
questions.answer: Rett syndrome causes regression in girls after normal development. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, treating seizures, nutritional support, and family support. Genetic condition. Mainly affects girls. Supportive care improves quality of life.

questions.question: Angelman
questions.answer: Angelman syndrome causes developmental delays, seizures, and happy demeanor. Treatment includes managing seizures, physical therapy, speech therapy, occupational therapy, behavioral interventions, and family support. Genetic condition. Early intervention helps development. Most remain non-verbal.

questions.question: Prader-Willi
questions.answer: Prader-Willi syndrome causes obesity, developmental delays, and behavioral problems. Treatment includes growth hormone therapy, strict dietary control, physical therapy, behavioral management, and family support. Genetic condition. Requires lifelong management. Food security essential to prevent obesity.

questions.question: Fragile-X
questions.answer: Fragile X syndrome causes intellectual disability and autism features. Treatment includes special education, speech therapy, occupational therapy, behavioral interventions, medications for hyperactivity or anxiety, and family support. Most common inherited intellectual disability. Early intervention helps.

questions.question: Down
questions.answer: Down syndrome causes intellectual disability and distinctive features. Treatment includes early intervention, speech therapy, physical therapy, occupational therapy, treating medical problems, special education, and family support. Most common chromosomal condition. Many live fulfilling lives.

questions.question: Williams
questions.answer: Williams syndrome causes developmental delays and cardiovascular problems. Treatment includes managing heart problems, speech therapy, occupational therapy, special education, treating anxiety, and family support. Genetic condition. Distinctive personality with social strength. Requires cardiac monitoring.

questions.question: Tuberous
questions.answer: Tuberous sclerosis causes tumors in multiple organs including brain. Treatment includes managing seizures, removing symptomatic brain tumors, treating skin lesions, monitoring kidneys and heart, and supportive care. Genetic condition. Severity varies widely. Regular screening for tumors needed.

questions.question: Neurofibromatosis
questions.answer: Neurofibromatosis causes tumors on nerves and skin. Treatment includes monitoring tumors, surgery for problematic tumors, managing complications, treating learning disabilities, genetic counseling, and regular screening. Type 1 most common. Requires lifelong monitoring.

questions.question: Sturge-Weber
questions.answer: Sturge-Weber syndrome causes facial birthmark, seizures, and glaucoma. Treatment includes managing seizures, treating glaucoma, laser therapy for birthmark, monitoring development, and supportive care. Not inherited. Brain imaging shows characteristic pattern. Early treatment prevents complications.

questions.question: Von-Hippel-Lindau
questions.answer: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome causes tumors in multiple organs including brain. Treatment includes regular screening, surgery for symptomatic tumors, monitoring, genetic counseling, and family screening. Genetic condition. Requires lifelong surveillance. Early detection and treatment improve outcomes.

questions.question: Ataxia
questions.answer: Ataxia is lack of muscle coordination affecting balance and movement. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, assistive devices, treating underlying causes, speech therapy if needed, and adaptive equipment. Many causes exist. Treatment depends on type. Therapy maintains function.

questions.question: Cerebellar
questions.answer: Cerebellar disorders affect coordination and balance. Treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, treating underlying causes, assistive devices, and adaptive strategies. Cerebellum coordinates movement. Damage causes specific pattern of symptoms. Rehabilitation helps compensation.

questions.question: Brainstem
questions.answer: Brainstem disorders are serious affecting vital functions. Treatment depends on cause but includes respiratory support, managing blood pressure, treating underlying stroke or tumor, intensive care, and rehabilitation. Controls breathing and consciousness. Damage can be life-threatening.

questions.question: Thalamic
questions.answer: Thalamic disorders affect sensation and consciousness. Treatment includes managing pain which can be severe, physical therapy, occupational therapy, treating underlying stroke or tumor, and pain medications. Thalamus is sensory relay station. Damage causes specific pain syndromes.

questions.question: Hypothalamic
questions.answer: Hypothalamic disorders affect hormones, temperature, and appetite. Treatment includes hormone replacement, managing temperature, treating obesity or weight loss, addressing sleep problems, and treating underlying causes. Regulates many body functions. Requires endocrine management.

questions.question: Hippocampal
questions.answer: Hippocampal disorders primarily affect memory formation. Treatment includes cognitive therapy, memory strategies, treating seizures if present, addressing underlying causes, and supportive care. Essential for new memories. Damage causes specific amnesia pattern. Can't form new memories.

questions.question: Frontal
questions.answer: Frontal lobe disorders affect personality, planning, and behavior. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, treating impulsivity, family education, managing mood changes, treating underlying injury or degeneration, and supportive care. Controls executive functions. Damage causes distinctive behavioral changes.

questions.question: Temporal
questions.answer: Temporal lobe disorders affect memory and language. Treatment includes managing seizures which are common, speech therapy, memory strategies, treating underlying causes, and supportive care. Important for memory and hearing. Seizures often originate here.

questions.question: Parietal
questions.answer: Parietal lobe disorders affect sensation and spatial awareness. Treatment includes occupational therapy, treating neglect, sensory retraining, managing pain, treating underlying causes, and adaptive strategies. Processes sensory information. Damage causes characteristic syndromes.

questions.question: Occipital
questions.answer: Occipital lobe disorders affect vision. Treatment includes vision therapy, using remaining vision, occupational therapy, treating underlying stroke or tumor, and adaptive strategies. Visual cortex located here. Damage causes specific visual deficits despite normal eyes.

questions.question: Corpus-Callosum
questions.answer: Corpus callosum disorders affect communication between brain hemispheres. Treatment includes managing developmental delays, physical therapy, occupational therapy, treating seizures, and supportive care. Can be absent from birth or damaged by injury. Each hemisphere works independently.

questions.question: Basal-Ganglia
questions.answer: Basal ganglia disorders cause movement problems. Treatment includes medications like levodopa, physical therapy, occupational therapy, treating underlying conditions, and sometimes surgery. Controls movement initiation. Includes Parkinson's and Huntington's. Various movement disorders result.

questions.question: Limbic
questions.answer: Limbic system disorders affect emotions and memory. Treatment includes medications for mood, therapy, treating underlying encephalitis or seizures, and supportive care. Emotional brain. Damage causes mood and memory problems. Limbic encephalitis is autoimmune condition.

questions.question: White-Matter
questions.answer: White matter disorders affect nerve connections. Treatment includes treating underlying conditions like MS, physical therapy, occupational therapy, managing symptoms, and supportive care. Connects brain regions. Many causes from genetic to acquired. MRI shows characteristic changes.

questions.question: Gray-Matter
questions.answer: Gray matter disorders affect nerve cell bodies. Treatment depends on cause but includes managing symptoms, physical therapy, treating underlying degeneration or injury, and supportive care. Contains neuron cell bodies. Various diseases affect specifically. Different from white matter disorders.

questions.question: Myelin
questions.answer: Myelin disorders affect nerve insulation. Treatment includes treating underlying MS or leukodystrophy, immunotherapy for autoimmune types, physical therapy, and supportive care. Insulates nerve fibers. Loss causes various neurological problems. Can be genetic or acquired.

questions.question: Axonal
questions.answer: Axonal disorders affect nerve fibers. Treatment includes treating underlying neuropathy, physical therapy, pain management, treating causes like diabetes, and supportive care. Nerve fiber damage. Different from myelin disorders. Often from metabolic or toxic causes.

questions.question: Dendritic
questions.answer: Dendritic disorders affect nerve connections. Treatment focuses on managing underlying neurodevelopmental or degenerative conditions, cognitive therapy, supportive care, and treating symptoms. Dendrites receive signals. Abnormalities in development or degeneration. Affects learning and cognition.

questions.question: Synaptic
questions.answer: Synaptic disorders affect nerve signal transmission. Treatment includes medications to improve transmission, treating underlying autoimmune conditions, physical therapy, and supportive care. Connections between neurons. Various conditions affect. Includes myasthenia and some dementias.

questions.question: Neurotransmitter
questions.answer: Neurotransmitter disorders affect brain chemical messengers. Treatment includes medications to supplement or block specific neurotransmitters, dietary modifications, treating underlying conditions, and supportive care. Brain chemicals for communication. Many psychiatric and neurological conditions involve these.

questions.question: Dopamine
questions.answer: Dopamine disorders include Parkinson's and psychosis. Treatment includes dopamine medications for Parkinson's, antipsychotics that block dopamine for psychosis, managing side effects, and monitoring. Important neurotransmitter. Too little causes Parkinson's. Too much activity causes psychosis.

questions.question: Serotonin
questions.answer: Serotonin disorders include depression and anxiety. Treatment includes SSRI medications, therapy, lifestyle changes, exercise, and monitoring. Mood neurotransmitter. Low levels associated with depression. Medications increase availability. Also involved in sleep and appetite.

questions.question: Acetylcholine
questions.answer: Acetylcholine disorders include myasthenia and dementia. Treatment includes medications to increase levels for dementia, medications to improve transmission for myasthenia, and managing symptoms. Muscle and memory neurotransmitter. Low in Alzheimer's. Blocked in myasthenia.

questions.question: GABA
questions.answer: GABA disorders include anxiety and epilepsy. Treatment includes medications that enhance GABA like benzodiazepines and some seizure medications, therapy, and managing symptoms. Inhibitory neurotransmitter. Calms brain activity. Low activity causes anxiety and seizures.

questions.question: Glutamate
questions.answer: Glutamate disorders include stroke damage and some dementias. Treatment includes protecting against excess glutamate, treating underlying conditions, managing symptoms, and supportive care. Excitatory neurotransmitter. Too much causes cell death. Involved in learning and memory.

questions.question: Norepinephrine
questions.answer: Norepinephrine disorders include depression and ADHD. Treatment includes medications like SNRIs for depression, stimulants for ADHD, therapy, and lifestyle changes. Alertness neurotransmitter. Low in depression. Medications for ADHD increase levels. Also called noradrenaline.

questions.question: Endorphin
questions.answer: Endorphin deficiency affects pain and mood. Treatment includes exercise which increases endorphins, treating underlying depression, pain management, acupuncture, and lifestyle changes. Natural pain relievers. Released with exercise. Runner's high from endorphins. Help regulate mood.

questions.question: Oxytocin
questions.answer: Oxytocin disorders affect bonding and social behavior. Treatment includes therapy for social difficulties, treating underlying autism or social anxiety, and managing symptoms. Bonding hormone. Important for social connections. Low in some autism cases. Research ongoing for treatments.

questions.question: Melatonin
questions.answer: Melatonin disorders affect sleep-wake cycles. Treatment includes melatonin supplements, maintaining sleep schedule, light therapy, treating underlying conditions, avoiding screens before bed, and good sleep hygiene. Sleep hormone. Low causes insomnia. Supplements widely available and generally safe.

questions.question: Cortisol
questions.answer: Cortisol imbalance affects stress response and brain function. Treatment includes managing stress, treating underlying adrenal problems, medications to regulate levels, lifestyle changes, adequate sleep, and regular exercise. Stress hormone. High levels damage brain over time. Low levels cause fatigue and confusion.

questions.question: Thyroid
questions.answer: Thyroid problems affect brain function and mood. Treatment includes thyroid hormone replacement for low levels, medications to reduce for high levels, regular monitoring, and treating symptoms. Low thyroid causes depression and memory problems. High thyroid causes anxiety and tremors.

questions.question: Hypoglycemia
questions.answer: Hypoglycemia is low blood sugar affecting brain function. Treatment includes eating fast-acting sugar immediately, regular meals and snacks, treating underlying diabetes, monitoring blood sugar, and carrying glucose tablets. Brain needs constant glucose. Severe cases cause confusion and seizures.

questions.question: Hyperglycemia
questions.answer: Hyperglycemia is high blood sugar damaging nerves and brain. Treatment includes insulin or diabetes medications, dietary changes, exercise, monitoring blood sugar, staying hydrated, and treating underlying diabetes. Chronic high sugar damages blood vessels and nerves. Prevention of complications important.

questions.question: Hypoxia
questions.answer: Hypoxia is reduced oxygen to brain. Treatment requires immediate oxygen therapy, treating underlying lung or heart problems, hospitalization, monitoring, and rehabilitation if brain damage occurred. Medical emergency. Brain damage occurs within minutes. Prevention includes treating respiratory problems.

questions.question: Anoxia
questions.answer: Anoxia is complete lack of oxygen to brain. Treatment requires immediate resuscitation, oxygen therapy, intensive care, treating underlying cause, cooling therapy to protect brain, and rehabilitation. More severe than hypoxia. Causes rapid brain damage. Emergency treatment critical.

questions.question: Ischemia
questions.answer: Ischemia is reduced blood flow to brain. Treatment includes emergency stroke treatment, blood thinners, controlling risk factors, surgery for blocked arteries, and rehabilitation. Causes stroke if prolonged. Time is brain. Quick treatment prevents permanent damage.

questions.question: Edema
questions.answer: Brain edema is dangerous swelling. Treatment includes medications to reduce swelling, treating underlying injury or infection, monitoring pressure, sometimes surgery to relieve pressure, and intensive care. Can be life-threatening. Increased pressure damages brain. Various causes need specific treatments.

questions.question: Herniation
questions.answer: Brain herniation is life-threatening brain shift from pressure. Treatment requires emergency surgery to relieve pressure, medications, intensive care, and treating underlying cause. Medical emergency. Brain pushed through skull openings. Usually fatal without immediate treatment.

questions.question: Atrophy
questions.answer: Brain atrophy is tissue loss from aging or disease. Treatment includes managing underlying dementia or other causes, cognitive stimulation, physical exercise, social engagement, healthy diet, and treating risk factors. Normal with aging. Excessive atrophy indicates disease. Cannot reverse but can slow.

questions.question: Lesion
questions.answer: Brain lesions are abnormal areas on scans. Treatment depends on cause including monitoring, surgery, radiation, treating MS or infection, and managing symptoms. Many possible causes. Can be benign or serious. Further testing determines type and treatment needed.

questions.question: Plaques
questions.answer: Brain plaques indicate Alzheimer's or MS. Treatment includes medications for Alzheimer's to slow progression, treating MS with disease-modifying drugs, managing symptoms, and supportive care. Protein deposits in Alzheimer's. Demyelination patches in MS. Different diseases, different treatments.

questions.question: Tangles
questions.answer: Neurofibrillary tangles are hallmark of Alzheimer's disease. Treatment includes medications to manage symptoms, cognitive therapy, maintaining activity, treating behavioral problems, and family support. Twisted protein fibers inside neurons. Correlate with dementia severity. Cannot be removed currently.

questions.question: Amyloid
questions.answer: Amyloid plaques accumulate in Alzheimer's disease. Treatment includes medications to reduce production, managing symptoms, clinical trials for removal therapies, lifestyle interventions, and supportive care. Protein deposits between neurons. Target of new treatments. Early detection important.

questions.question: Tau
questions.answer: Tau protein tangles damage brain in Alzheimer's and other dementias. Treatment includes managing symptoms, clinical trials targeting tau, supportive care, and treating behavioral problems. Normally stabilizes neurons. Becomes tangled in disease. Spreads through brain over time.

questions.question: Lewy
questions.answer: Lewy bodies cause dementia and Parkinson's symptoms. Treatment includes medications for movement and cognition, treating hallucinations carefully, managing behavior, physical therapy, and family support. Protein deposits in brain. Cause Parkinson's and specific dementia type. Sensitive to antipsychotics.

questions.question: Calcification
questions.answer: Brain calcification is calcium deposits visible on scans. Treatment includes monitoring, treating underlying conditions if any, managing symptoms if present, and regular follow-up. Often incidental finding. Can be normal with aging. Sometimes indicates previous infection.

questions.question: Gliosis
questions.answer: Gliosis is scar tissue formation in brain. Treatment focuses on underlying cause like injury or MS, managing symptoms, preventing further damage, and supportive care. Brain's scarring response. Seen on MRI. Indicates previous damage. Cannot reverse but stabilizes.

questions.question: Demyelination
questions.answer: Demyelination is loss of nerve insulation. Treatment includes treating underlying MS or other causes, immunotherapy, steroids for acute episodes, physical therapy, and disease-modifying drugs. Myelin sheath damaged. Slows nerve signals. MS is most common cause.

questions.question: Remyelination
questions.answer: Remyelination is repair of nerve insulation. Treatment includes treating underlying MS, promoting natural repair with medications in trials, managing symptoms, and maintaining function. Brain's natural repair. Incomplete in MS. Research focuses on enhancing this process.

questions.question: Neuroplasticity
questions.answer: Neuroplasticity is brain's ability to reorganize after injury. Treatment maximizes this through intensive rehabilitation, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, cognitive exercises, and repetitive practice. Brain forms new connections. Basis of stroke recovery. Greater in young brains.

questions.question: Neurogenesis
questions.answer: Neurogenesis is formation of new brain cells. Treatment to promote includes regular exercise, mental stimulation, adequate sleep, stress reduction, and healthy diet. Occurs in specific brain areas. Exercise increases this process. Important for memory and mood.

questions.question: Apoptosis
questions.answer: Apoptosis is programmed cell death, excessive in neurodegenerative diseases. Treatment includes medications to prevent excessive death, treating underlying conditions, neuroprotective strategies, and managing symptoms. Normal process. Excessive in Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Research targets reducing abnormal apoptosis.

questions.question: Necrosis
questions.answer: Necrosis is cell death from injury. Treatment includes preventing further damage, treating underlying stroke or trauma, managing swelling, rehabilitation, and supportive care. Uncontrolled cell death. Causes inflammation. Occurs in stroke and injury. Different from apoptosis.

questions.question: Inflammation
questions.answer: Brain inflammation occurs in many conditions. Treatment includes steroids to reduce inflammation, treating underlying infection or autoimmune disease, immunotherapy, and managing symptoms. Part of injury response. Excessive inflammation harmful. Balance needed for healing.

questions.question: Autoimmune
questions.answer: Autoimmune brain disorders include MS and encephalitis. Treatment includes immunosuppressants, steroids, plasma exchange, treating relapses, disease-modifying drugs, and managing symptoms. Immune system attacks brain. Many types exist. Early treatment prevents damage.

questions.question: Oxidative
questions.answer: Oxidative stress damages brain cells in aging and disease. Treatment includes antioxidant-rich diet, treating underlying conditions, healthy lifestyle, exercise, and managing risk factors. Free radical damage. Contributes to degeneration. Antioxidants may help protect.

questions.question: Mitochondrial
questions.answer: Mitochondrial disorders affect brain energy production. Treatment includes supplements like coenzyme Q10, treating symptoms, avoiding triggers, managing complications, and supportive care. Energy factories of cells. Genetic disorders. Brain highly energy-dependent. Many symptoms possible.

questions.question: Metabolic
questions.answer: Metabolic brain disorders affect chemistry balance. Treatment includes correcting imbalances, treating underlying liver or kidney problems, dietary modifications, supplements, and managing symptoms. Various causes. Can be acute or chronic. Reversible if caught early.

questions.question: Toxicity
questions.answer: Brain toxicity from drugs or poisons requires immediate treatment. Treatment includes stopping toxic substance, supportive care, sometimes antidotes, treating symptoms, and rehabilitation if damage occurred. Many substances toxic to brain. Prevention through avoiding exposure. Variable recovery.

questions.question: Withdrawal
questions.answer: Withdrawal from alcohol or drugs affects brain. Treatment includes medical supervision, medications to ease symptoms, preventing seizures, treating delirium, hydration, and rehabilitation programs. Can be dangerous. Alcohol withdrawal causes seizures. Medical detox safest.

questions.question: Addiction
questions.answer: Addiction changes brain reward circuits. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, medications for some addictions, support groups, treating underlying mental health issues, residential treatment if needed, and long-term follow-up. Brain disease, not moral failing. Recovery possible with treatment.

questions.question: Tolerance
questions.answer: Drug tolerance means needing more for same effect. Treatment includes supervised dose reduction, switching medications, treating underlying pain or condition differently, and avoiding escalation. Brain adapts to drugs. Can lead to dependence. Medical management needed.

questions.question: Dependence
questions.answer: Physical dependence causes withdrawal when stopping. Treatment includes gradual tapering, switching to longer-acting drugs, medical supervision, managing withdrawal symptoms, and addressing addiction if present. Physical adaptation. Different from addiction. Medical guidance needed for stopping.

questions.question: Intoxication
questions.answer: Acute intoxication affects brain function temporarily. Treatment includes supportive care, monitoring, treating dangerous symptoms, preventing aspiration, letting substance wear off, and addressing addiction. Temporary effect. Can be dangerous. Some substances have specific antidotes.

questions.question: Delirium-Tremens
questions.answer: Delirium tremens is severe alcohol withdrawal. Treatment requires hospitalization, benzodiazepines, IV fluids, thiamine, managing hallucinations and agitation, preventing complications, and intensive monitoring. Medical emergency. Can be fatal. Occurs in heavy drinkers stopping suddenly.

questions.question: Korsakoff
questions.answer: Korsakoff syndrome causes severe memory problems from alcohol. Treatment includes thiamine replacement, stopping alcohol, structured environment, memory aids, nutritional support, and long-term care. Often follows Wernicke's. Memory rarely recovers. Prevention crucial.

questions.question: Fetal-Alcohol
questions.answer: Fetal alcohol syndrome causes brain damage from pregnancy alcohol exposure. Treatment includes early intervention, special education, behavioral therapy, treating ADHD and other problems, family support, and structured environment. Preventable. Lifelong effects. No safe alcohol level in pregnancy.

questions.question: Radiation
questions.answer: Radiation damage to brain can occur from treatment. Treatment includes steroids for swelling, cognitive therapy, treating fatigue, managing symptoms, and supportive care. Side effect of brain tumor treatment. Can be delayed months. Balance of benefits versus risks.

questions.question: Chemotherapy
questions.answer: Chemotherapy can cause brain fog and memory problems. Treatment includes cognitive rehabilitation, treating fatigue, managing mood, exercise, brain training, and patience as often improves. Called chemo brain. Usually temporary. Some drugs more problematic than others.

questions.question: Immunotherapy
questions.answer: Immunotherapy can cause brain inflammation as side effect. Treatment includes stopping immunotherapy temporarily, steroids, managing symptoms, monitoring closely, and resuming carefully. New cancer treatment. Can affect nervous system. Usually reversible with treatment.

questions.question: Steroid
questions.answer: Steroids can cause mood and cognitive changes. Treatment includes using lowest effective dose, tapering slowly, treating psychiatric symptoms, monitoring, and considering alternatives. Used for many brain conditions. Side effects common. Never stop suddenly.

questions.question: Anticoagulant
questions.answer: Anticoagulants prevent strokes but increase bleeding risk. Treatment includes regular monitoring, careful dosing, avoiding interactions, reporting bruising or bleeding, and carrying medical alert. Blood thinners. Prevent clot strokes. Bleeding risk needs careful balance.

questions.question: Antiepileptic
questions.answer: Antiepileptic drugs control seizures. Treatment includes finding right medication and dose, taking regularly, monitoring levels, managing side effects, and never stopping suddenly. Many options available. Most people achieve seizure control. Regular medication essential.

questions.question: Antipsychotic
questions.answer: Antipsychotics treat psychosis and agitation. Treatment includes careful dosing, monitoring for side effects like movement disorders, regular check-ups, treating metabolic effects, and considering newer options. Manage serious symptoms. Side effects significant. Benefit-risk assessment important.

questions.question: Antidepressant
questions.answer: Antidepressants treat depression and anxiety. Treatment includes trying for adequate time, monitoring response, managing side effects, tapering slowly when stopping, and combining with therapy. Take weeks to work. Many types available. Often need to try different ones.

questions.question: Anxiolytic
questions.answer: Anxiolytics reduce anxiety. Treatment includes short-term use preferred, avoiding dependence, using as-needed rather than scheduled, combining with therapy, and considering non-medication options. Include benzodiazepines. Risk of dependence. Better options for long-term use.

questions.question: Stimulant
questions.answer: Stimulants treat ADHD and narcolepsy. Treatment includes careful dosing, monitoring growth in children, drug holidays sometimes, managing sleep and appetite, and watching for abuse. Improve focus. Controlled substances. Need regular monitoring.

questions.question: Sedative
questions.answer: Sedatives cause drowsiness and sleep. Treatment includes short-term use, avoiding driving, preventing dependence, tapering when stopping, and considering alternatives. Include benzodiazepines and sleeping pills. Risk of dependence and falls. Non-drug approaches often better.

questions.question: Hypnotic
questions.answer: Hypnotics are sleeping medications. Treatment includes short-term use only, sleep hygiene first, cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, avoiding long-term use, and tapering slowly. Help with sleep. Risk of dependence. Often lose effectiveness. Behavior changes more effective long-term.

questions.question: Analgesic
questions.answer: Analgesics relieve pain. Treatment includes using appropriate type for pain, avoiding overuse headaches, monitoring for side effects, combining with non-drug approaches, and careful opioid use. Many types. Overuse causes problems. Multimodal approach best.

questions.question: Opioid
questions.answer: Opioids are strong pain relievers with addiction risk. Treatment includes careful prescribing, monitoring for addiction, preventing overdose with naloxone, tapering slowly, and considering alternatives. Effective for severe pain. High addiction risk. Overdose crisis ongoing.

questions.question: Benzodiazepine
questions.answer: Benzodiazepines treat anxiety and seizures. Treatment includes short-term use, avoiding alcohol, slow tapering when stopping, monitoring for dependence, and considering alternatives. Effective but addictive. Withdrawal dangerous. Should not stop suddenly.

questions.question: Barbiturate
questions.answer: Barbiturates are older sedatives rarely used now. Treatment includes careful dosing, monitoring levels, avoiding with alcohol, slow tapering, and using safer alternatives when possible. Narrow safety margin. High overdose risk. Mostly replaced by benzodiazepines.

questions.question: Anticholinergic
questions.answer: Anticholinergics block acetylcholine causing memory problems. Treatment includes using alternatives especially in elderly, minimizing dose, monitoring cognition, avoiding multiple such drugs, and stopping if possible. Many drugs have this effect. Worsen dementia. Common in elderly.

questions.question: Cholinesterase
questions.answer: Cholinesterase inhibitors treat Alzheimer's disease. Treatment includes starting low and increasing slowly, managing side effects like nausea, continuing if helping, monitoring response, and realistic expectations. Modest benefit. Don't cure. May slow decline temporarily.

questions.question: Memantine
questions.answer: Memantine treats moderate to severe Alzheimer's. Treatment includes combining with cholinesterase inhibitor, managing side effects, monitoring response, continuing if beneficial, and realistic goals. Different mechanism than other Alzheimer's drugs. Modest benefit. Better tolerated.

questions.question: Levodopa
questions.answer: Levodopa treats Parkinson's disease. Treatment includes taking with carbidopa, timing doses, managing wearing-off, avoiding protein competition, adjusting dose over time, and managing side effects. Most effective Parkinson's drug. Becomes less effective over time. Timing crucial.

questions.question: Dopamine-Agonist
questions.answer: Dopamine agonists treat Parkinson's disease. Treatment includes starting low, watching for impulse control problems, managing side effects, adjusting dose, and combining with levodopa. Alternative to levodopa. Side effects include compulsive behaviors. Lower doses than levodopa.

questions.question: MAO-Inhibitor
questions.answer: MAO inhibitors treat Parkinson's and depression. Treatment includes avoiding tyramine foods, watching for interactions, monitoring blood pressure, following dietary restrictions, and careful with other medications. Older drugs. Dietary restrictions needed. Drug interactions common.

questions.question: COMT-Inhibitor
questions.answer: COMT inhibitors extend levodopa effectiveness. Treatment includes taking with levodopa, managing diarrhea side effect, watching for dyskinesia increase, adjusting levodopa dose, and monitoring. Used with levodopa. Reduces wearing-off. Allows lower levodopa doses.

questions.question: Botulinum
questions.answer: Botulinum toxin treats spasticity, dystonia, and migraines. Treatment includes injections every three months, finding right muscles and doses, managing temporary weakness, repeating as needed, and realistic expectations. Very effective for focal problems. Temporary effect. Generally safe.

questions.question: Interferon
questions.answer: Interferon treats multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes injections, managing flu-like side effects, monitoring blood counts and liver, watching for depression, and considering newer alternatives. Older MS drug. Frequent injections. Many side effects. Better drugs now available.

questions.question: Glatiramer
questions.answer: Glatiramer treats multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes daily injections, managing injection site reactions, rotating sites, continuing long-term, and monitoring. MS disease-modifying drug. Daily injections needed. Generally well-tolerated. Reduces relapses.

questions.question: Natalizumab
questions.answer: Natalizumab treats multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes monthly infusions, monitoring for PML risk, checking JC virus status, watching for infections, and regular MRI monitoring. Very effective MS drug. Risk of serious brain infection. Careful monitoring required.

questions.question: Ocrelizumab
questions.answer: Ocrelizumab treats multiple sclerosis including progressive type. Treatment includes twice-yearly infusions, monitoring for infections, managing infusion reactions, checking immunoglobulins, and regular follow-up. Newer MS drug. Treats progressive MS. Given twice yearly. Generally well-tolerated.

questions.question: Fingolimod
questions.answer: Fingolimod treats multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes daily pill, first-dose monitoring, eye exams, checking heart rhythm, monitoring infections, and avoiding live vaccines. First oral MS drug. Convenient. Requires monitoring. Various side effects possible.

questions.question: Teriflunomide
questions.answer: Teriflunomide treats multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes daily pill, monitoring liver function, checking blood pressure, avoiding pregnancy, and regular follow-up. Oral MS drug. Once daily. Monitoring needed. Pregnancy must be avoided.

questions.question: Dimethyl-Fumarate
questions.answer: Dimethyl fumarate treats multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes twice-daily pills, managing flushing and stomach upset, monitoring blood counts, checking kidney function, and taking with food. Oral MS drug. Common side effects. Usually improve over time. Generally effective.

questions.question: Mitoxantrone
questions.answer: Mitoxantrone treats aggressive multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes infusions, monitoring heart function, checking blood counts, limited lifetime dose, and careful patient selection. Chemotherapy drug for MS. Reserved for aggressive cases. Heart toxicity limits use.

questions.question: Riluzole
questions.answer: Riluzole treats ALS to slow progression. Treatment includes twice-daily dosing, monitoring liver function, managing side effects, realistic expectations, and combining with supportive care. Only drug approved for ALS. Modest benefit. Slows progression slightly.

questions.question: Edaravone
questions.answer: Edaravone treats ALS. Treatment includes IV infusions in cycles, monitoring function, combining with riluzole, managing disease progression, and supportive care. Second approved ALS drug. Preserves function slightly. Requires infusions. Used in selected patients.

questions.question: Baclofen
questions.answer: Baclofen treats spasticity. Treatment includes starting low and increasing slowly, taking regularly, avoiding sudden stops, intrathecal pump for severe cases, and monitoring effectiveness. Muscle relaxant. Effective for spasticity. Can't stop suddenly. Pump delivers directly to spinal cord.

questions.question: Tizanidine
questions.answer: Tizanidine treats spasticity and muscle spasms. Treatment includes starting low, managing drowsiness, checking liver function, avoiding with certain drugs, and timing doses. Muscle relaxant. Causes drowsiness. Helpful for nighttime spasticity. Liver monitoring needed.

questions.question: Dantrolene
questions.answer: Dantrolene treats spasticity and malignant hyperthermia. Treatment includes regular dosing, monitoring liver function, managing weakness, checking effectiveness, and long-term monitoring. Works on muscles directly. Can cause liver problems. Monitoring essential.

questions.question: Modafinil
questions.answer: Modafinil treats narcolepsy and excessive sleepiness. Treatment includes morning dosing, monitoring blood pressure, avoiding late-day doses, watching for side effects, and combining with sleep hygiene. Promotes wakefulness. Not addictive. Helps daytime alertness.

questions.question: Methylphenidate
questions.answer: Methylphenidate treats ADHD and narcolepsy. Treatment includes finding right dose and formulation, monitoring growth in children, drug holidays considered, managing sleep and appetite, and watching for abuse. Stimulant. Controlled substance. Improves focus. Various formulations available.

questions.question: Amphetamine
questions.answer: Amphetamine treats ADHD and narcolepsy. Treatment includes careful dosing, monitoring cardiovascular effects, managing sleep and appetite, watching for abuse, and regular follow-up. Stimulant. Controlled substance. Effective for ADHD. Cardiovascular monitoring needed.

questions.question: Atomoxetine
questions.answer: Atomoxetine treats ADHD without being a stimulant. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring mood, checking heart rate and blood pressure, takes weeks to work, and alternative for stimulant concerns. Non-stimulant ADHD drug. Not controlled substance. Takes longer to work.

questions.question: Guanfacine
questions.answer: Guanfacine treats ADHD and tics. Treatment includes once or twice daily dosing, monitoring blood pressure, avoiding sudden stops, combining with stimulants possible, and managing side effects. Blood pressure drug used for ADHD. Helps hyperactivity and impulsivity. Not addictive.

questions.question: Clonidine
questions.answer: Clonidine treats ADHD, tics, and sleep problems. Treatment includes careful dosing, monitoring blood pressure, avoiding sudden stops, bedtime dosing for sleep, and patch option available. Blood pressure drug with multiple uses. Sedating. Helpful for sleep and tics.

questions.question: Carbamazepine
questions.answer: Carbamazepine treats seizures and nerve pain. Treatment includes monitoring blood levels, checking blood counts, watching for rash, avoiding interactions, and regular follow-up. Older seizure drug. Many drug interactions. Monitoring needed. Also treats trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.question: Valproate
questions.answer: Valproate treats seizures and bipolar disorder. Treatment includes monitoring levels, checking liver function, avoiding in pregnancy, managing weight gain, and watching for tremor. Broad spectrum seizure drug. Mood stabilizer. Causes birth defects. Weight gain common.

questions.question: Phenytoin
questions.answer: Phenytoin treats seizures. Treatment includes monitoring blood levels, dental care important, checking for side effects, avoiding interactions, and regular follow-up. Old seizure drug. Narrow therapeutic range. Gum overgrowth side effect. Many interactions.

questions.question: Lamotrigine
questions.answer: Lamotrigine treats seizures and bipolar disorder. Treatment includes very slow dose increase, watching for rash, checking effectiveness, combining with other drugs, and regular monitoring. Newer seizure drug. Must increase slowly. Serious rash possible. Mood stabilizer.

questions.question: Levetiracetam
questions.answer: Levetiracetam treats seizures. Treatment includes twice-daily dosing, monitoring mood changes, adjusting for kidney function, combining with other drugs, and watching for irritability. Newer seizure drug. Generally well-tolerated. Few interactions. Mood changes possible.

questions.question: Topiramate
questions.answer: Topiramate treats seizures, migraines, and helps weight loss. Treatment includes slow dose increase, staying hydrated, monitoring for kidney stones, watching for cognitive effects, and checking eye pressure. Multiple uses. Causes weight loss. Cognitive slowing possible.

questions.question: Gabapentin
questions.answer: Gabapentin treats nerve pain and seizures. Treatment includes three times daily dosing, adjusting for kidney function, avoiding sudden stops, managing dizziness, and increasing slowly. Well-tolerated. Helps nerve pain. Multiple daily doses needed. Dizziness common initially.

questions.question: Pregabalin
questions.answer: Pregabalin treats nerve pain, fibromyalgia, and seizures. Treatment includes twice-daily dosing, managing weight gain and dizziness, adjusting for kidney function, avoiding sudden stops, and monitoring effectiveness. Similar to gabapentin. Fewer daily doses. Weight gain possible.

questions.question: Oxcarbazepine
questions.answer: Oxcarbazepine treats seizures and nerve pain. Treatment includes monitoring sodium levels, watching for rash, increasing dose slowly, checking effectiveness, and regular follow-up. Related to carbamazepine. Better tolerated. Fewer interactions. Low sodium possible.

questions.question: Zonisamide
questions.answer: Zonisamide treats seizures. Treatment includes monitoring for kidney stones, staying hydrated, watching for side effects, checking effectiveness, and slow dose adjustment. Newer seizure drug. Multiple mechanisms. Kidney stone risk. Sulfa allergy caution.

questions.question: Perampanel
questions.answer: Perampanel treats seizures. Treatment includes bedtime dosing, monitoring mood and behavior, slow dose increase, watching for dizziness, and regular follow-up. Newer seizure drug. Once-daily dosing. Mood changes possible. Bedtime dosing reduces side effects.

questions.question: Lacosamide
questions.answer: Lacosamide treats seizures. Treatment includes twice-daily dosing, monitoring heart rhythm, checking for dizziness, adjusting dose slowly, and ECG monitoring. Newer seizure drug. Heart rhythm effects. Generally well-tolerated. Few interactions.

questions.question: Brivaracetam
questions.answer: Brivaracetam treats seizures. Treatment includes twice-daily dosing, monitoring mood, watching for side effects, checking effectiveness, and adjusting dose. Related to levetiracetam. Mood changes possible. Generally well-tolerated. Fewer drug interactions.

questions.question: Cannabidiol
questions.answer: Cannabidiol treats certain rare seizures. Treatment includes twice-daily dosing, monitoring liver function, watching for interactions, checking blood levels, and managing diarrhea. CBD from marijuana plant. Approved for rare epilepsies. Liver monitoring needed.

questions.question: Sumatriptan
questions.answer: Sumatriptan treats acute migraines. Treatment includes taking early in attack, limiting use to prevent overuse headaches, various forms available, avoiding with heart disease, and combining with preventive drugs. Triptan class. Very effective. Multiple administration routes.

questions.question: Propranolol
questions.answer: Propranolol prevents migraines and treats tremor. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring blood pressure and pulse, avoiding sudden stops, managing fatigue, and checking effectiveness. Beta-blocker. Prevents migraines. Also treats tremor and anxiety.

questions.question: Amitriptyline
questions.answer: Amitriptyline prevents migraines and treats pain. Treatment includes bedtime dosing, starting low, managing dry mouth and drowsiness, avoiding in elderly, and monitoring effectiveness. Old antidepressant. Good for prevention. Sedating. Multiple pain uses.

questions.question: Ergotamine
questions.answer: Ergotamine treats acute migraines. Treatment includes limiting frequency to prevent rebound headaches, avoiding in pregnancy and heart disease, using early in attack, and considering newer alternatives. Older migraine drug. Risk of overuse. Triptans usually preferred.

questions.question: CGRP
questions.answer: CGRP inhibitors prevent migraines. Treatment includes monthly or quarterly injections, monitoring effectiveness, generally well-tolerated, expensive but effective, and alternative when others fail. Newest migraine preventives. Very effective. Few side effects. Given by injection.

questions.question: Lithium
questions.answer: Lithium treats bipolar disorder. Treatment includes regular blood level monitoring, checking kidney and thyroid function, staying hydrated, maintaining salt intake, watching for tremor and other side effects, and regular follow-up. Oldest mood stabilizer. Effective. Narrow therapeutic range. Requires monitoring.

questions.question: Quetiapine
questions.answer: Quetiapine treats schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring weight and blood sugar, managing sedation, checking for movement disorders, and regular follow-up. Atypical antipsychotic. Sedating. Causes weight gain. Multiple uses.

questions.question: Risperidone
questions.answer: Risperidone treats schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Treatment includes monitoring prolactin levels, watching for movement disorders, checking weight and blood sugar, managing side effects, and regular follow-up. Atypical antipsychotic. Can cause prolactin elevation. Effective but side effects common.

questions.question: Olanzapine
questions.answer: Olanzapine treats schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Treatment includes monitoring weight and metabolic parameters closely, managing significant weight gain, checking blood sugar, lifestyle modifications, and regular follow-up. Very effective. Major weight gain risk. Metabolic monitoring essential.

questions.question: Aripiprazole
questions.answer: Aripiprazole treats schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring for restlessness, checking for movement disorders, watching mood, and regular follow-up. Atypical antipsychotic. Less weight gain. Restlessness common initially. Multiple indications.

questions.question: Haloperidol
questions.answer: Haloperidol treats psychosis and agitation. Treatment includes low doses preferred, monitoring for movement disorders, managing stiffness, watching for tardive dyskinesia, and considering newer alternatives. Older antipsychotic. High movement disorder risk. Effective for acute agitation.

questions.question: Clozapine
questions.answer: Clozapine treats treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Treatment includes weekly blood count monitoring, watching for seizures, managing weight gain, checking blood sugar, and regular follow-up. Most effective antipsychotic. Risk of low white blood cells. Requires special monitoring.

questions.question: Fluoxetine
questions.answer: Fluoxetine treats depression and anxiety. Treatment includes daily dosing, waiting weeks for effect, monitoring mood especially initially, managing side effects, and long half-life means stays in system. SSRI antidepressant. Long-acting. Generally well-tolerated.

questions.question: Sertraline
questions.answer: Sertraline treats depression, anxiety, and OCD. Treatment includes daily dosing, starting low and increasing, monitoring mood, managing GI side effects, and regular follow-up. SSRI antidepressant. Well-studied. Multiple approved uses. Generally safe.

questions.question: Escitalopram
questions.answer: Escitalopram treats depression and anxiety. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring mood, managing side effects, checking QT interval in high-risk patients, and regular follow-up. SSRI antidepressant. Well-tolerated. Effective. Few drug interactions.

questions.question: Paroxetine
questions.answer: Paroxetine treats depression and anxiety. Treatment includes daily dosing, avoiding sudden stops due to withdrawal, managing weight gain, monitoring mood, and slow tapering when stopping. SSRI antidepressant. Significant withdrawal if stopped suddenly. Weight gain common.

questions.question: Citalopram
questions.answer: Citalopram treats depression and anxiety. Treatment includes daily dosing, dose limits due to heart effects, checking QT interval if needed, monitoring mood, and managing side effects. SSRI antidepressant. Dose restrictions exist. Generally well-tolerated.

questions.question: Venlafaxine
questions.answer: Venlafaxine treats depression and anxiety. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring blood pressure, avoiding sudden stops, managing side effects, and slow tapering. SNRI antidepressant. Can raise blood pressure. Withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly.

questions.question: Duloxetine
questions.answer: Duloxetine treats depression, anxiety, and nerve pain. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring liver function, managing nausea initially, treating multiple pain conditions, and avoiding sudden stops. SNRI antidepressant. Multiple pain indications. Generally well-tolerated.

questions.question: Bupropion
questions.answer: Bupropion treats depression and helps smoking cessation. Treatment includes daily dosing, avoiding in seizure disorders, managing insomnia, no sexual side effects advantage, and combining with other antidepressants. Atypical antidepressant. Activating. Helps quit smoking.

questions.question: Mirtazapine
questions.answer: Mirtazapine treats depression and helps sleep and appetite. Treatment includes bedtime dosing, managing weight gain, using sedation therapeutically, monitoring effectiveness, and lower doses more sedating. Atypical antidepressant. Very sedating. Increases appetite and weight.

questions.question: Trazodone
questions.answer: Trazodone treats depression and insomnia. Treatment includes bedtime dosing for sleep, managing dizziness, low doses for insomnia, higher doses for depression, and monitoring effectiveness. Atypical antidepressant. Commonly used for sleep. Causes dizziness.

questions.question: Lorazepam
questions.answer: Lorazepam treats anxiety and seizures. Treatment includes short-term use, avoiding alcohol, preventing dependence, tapering slowly when stopping, and considering alternatives. Benzodiazepine. Fast-acting. Addictive. Short-term use only.

questions.question: Diazepam
questions.answer: Diazepam treats anxiety, muscle spasms, and seizures. Treatment includes short-term use, avoiding alcohol, slow tapering, managing sedation, and long half-life. Benzodiazepine. Long-acting. Multiple uses. Accumulates in body.

questions.question: Alprazolam
questions.answer: Alprazolam treats anxiety and panic disorder. Treatment includes short-term use, avoiding alcohol, significant addiction risk, difficult withdrawal, and tapering very slowly. Benzodiazepine. Very addictive. Short-acting. Difficult to stop.

questions.question: Clonazepam
questions.answer: Clonazepam treats anxiety, panic, and seizures. Treatment includes daily dosing, monitoring for dependence, avoiding sudden stops, managing sedation, and slow tapering. Benzodiazepine. Long-acting. Less frequent dosing. Addictive.

questions.question: Zolpidem
questions.answer: Zolpidem treats insomnia short-term. Treatment includes bedtime dosing only, staying in bed after taking, short-term use, watching for unusual behaviors, and avoiding alcohol. Sleeping pill. Short-acting. Complex sleep behaviors possible. Addictive potential.

questions.question: Eszopiclone
questions.answer: Eszopiclone treats insomnia. Treatment includes bedtime dosing, avoiding next-day activities if drowsy, short-term use preferred, managing metallic taste, and monitoring effectiveness. Sleeping pill. Longer-acting than zolpidem. Metallic taste common.

questions.question: Zaleplon
questions.answer: Zaleplon treats difficulty falling asleep. Treatment includes taking at bedtime or middle of night if 4 hours left, very short-acting, minimal next-day effects, and short-term use. Sleeping pill. Very short duration. Good for sleep onset.

questions.question: Ramelteon
questions.answer: Ramelteon treats insomnia without addiction risk. Treatment includes bedtime dosing, not a controlled substance, mimics melatonin, generally safe, and can use longer-term. Melatonin receptor agonist. Non-addictive. Safe profile. Less effective than other sleep aids.

questions.question: Melatonin
questions.answer: Melatonin helps sleep and jet lag. Treatment includes taking 30 minutes before bed, starting low dose, generally safe supplement, helps circadian rhythm, and timing important. Natural hormone supplement. Safe. Helps sleep onset. Variable quality.

questions.question: Donepezil
questions.answer: Donepezil treats Alzheimer's disease. Treatment includes daily dosing, starting low, managing nausea and diarrhea, continuing if beneficial, and realistic expectations. Cholinesterase inhibitor. Most commonly prescribed. Once-daily dosing. Modest benefit.

questions.question: Rivastigmine
questions.answer: Rivastigmine treats Alzheimer's and Parkinson's dementia. Treatment includes twice-daily pills or patch option, managing GI side effects, patch better tolerated, continuing if helping, and monitoring. Cholinesterase inhibitor. Patch available. GI side effects common.

questions.question: Galantamine
questions.answer: Galantamine treats Alzheimer's disease. Treatment includes twice-daily or once-daily extended release, managing nausea, taking with food, continuing if beneficial, and monitoring response. Cholinesterase inhibitor. Extended release option. Similar efficacy to others.

questions.question: Aducanumab
questions.answer: Aducanumab removes amyloid in Alzheimer's. Treatment includes monthly infusions, MRI monitoring for brain swelling, early Alzheimer's only, controversial approval, and expensive. Newest Alzheimer's drug. Removes plaques. Benefit unclear. Brain swelling risk.

questions.question: Acupuncture
questions.answer: Acupuncture treats pain and some neurological symptoms. Treatment includes finding licensed practitioner, series of sessions, managing expectations, combining with conventional treatment, and generally safe. Alternative therapy. Helps some pain conditions. Low risk. Evidence mixed.

questions.question: Massage
questions.answer: Massage treats muscle pain and tension. Treatment includes regular sessions, various techniques available, communicating with therapist, managing expectations, and combining with other treatments. Therapeutic touch. Relaxing. Helps muscle tension. Generally safe.

questions.question: Yoga
questions.answer: Yoga helps stress, flexibility, and some neurological conditions. Treatment includes finding appropriate class, starting gently, regular practice, modified poses if needed, and combining with medical treatment. Mind-body practice. Improves flexibility and stress. Generally safe.

questions.question: Meditation
questions.answer: Meditation reduces stress and anxiety. Treatment includes daily practice even if brief, various techniques available, apps helpful for beginners, combining with other treatments, and patience with learning. Mindfulness practice. Reduces stress. Free. Takes practice.

questions.question: Biofeedback
questions.answer: Biofeedback teaches body control for pain and stress. Treatment includes sessions with trained therapist, learning techniques, practicing at home, treating migraines and anxiety, and combining with other methods. Learning body control. Helps various conditions. Requires training.

questions.question: Neurofeedback
questions.answer: Neurofeedback trains brain wave patterns. Treatment includes multiple sessions, trained practitioner needed, treating ADHD and anxiety, evidence mixed, and expensive. EEG biofeedback. Controversial effectiveness. Requires many sessions. No harm but unclear benefit.

questions.question: Hypnosis
questions.answer: Hypnosis helps pain, anxiety, and habit control. Treatment includes sessions with trained hypnotherapist, not mind control, relaxed focused state, good for some conditions, and combining with conventional treatment. Therapeutic trance. Helps some people. Safe.

questions.question: Aromatherapy
questions.answer: Aromatherapy uses scents for relaxation and mood. Treatment includes essential oils, diffusers or topical application, helping stress and sleep, complementary not primary treatment, and generally safe. Scent therapy. Relaxing. Limited evidence. Low risk.

questions.question: Music-Therapy
questions.answer: Music therapy helps mood, cognition, and rehabilitation. Treatment includes sessions with music therapist, various techniques, helping dementia and stroke patients, engaging and enjoyable, and combining with other therapies. Therapeutic music use. Evidence-based. Enjoyable. Multiple benefits.

questions.question: Art-Therapy
questions.answer: Art therapy helps expression and emotional processing. Treatment includes sessions with art therapist, no artistic skill needed, helpful for trauma and emotions, creative outlet, and combining with talk therapy. Creative expression therapy. Processes emotions. Engaging.

questions.question: Exercise
questions.answer: Exercise benefits brain health and mood significantly. Treatment includes regular aerobic activity, starting slowly, 30 minutes most days, improving mood and cognition, and combining with medical treatment. Best brain medicine. Improves everything. Free. Start today.

questions.question: Diet
questions.answer: Healthy diet supports brain function. Treatment includes Mediterranean diet beneficial, reducing processed foods, adequate omega-3 fats, controlling sugar, and combining with exercise. Brain nutrition. Mediterranean diet best evidence. Affects mood and cognition.

questions.question: Sleep
questions.answer: Adequate sleep essential for brain health. Treatment includes 7-9 hours nightly, regular schedule, sleep hygiene, treating sleep disorders, and prioritizing sleep. Brain restoration. Affects everything. Most neglected health behavior. Critical importance.

questions.question: Hydration
questions.answer: Proper hydration maintains brain function. Treatment includes drinking adequate water, monitoring urine color, replacing fluids with exercise, avoiding excessive caffeine, and consistent intake. Brain needs water. Dehydration causes confusion. Simple but important.

questions.question: Socialization
questions.answer: Social connection protects brain health. Treatment includes maintaining friendships, joining groups, regular interaction, reducing isolation, and seeking support. Brain stimulation. Reduces dementia risk. Improves mood. Essential need.

questions.question: Cognitive-Training
questions.answer: Brain training exercises may help cognition. Treatment includes puzzles and games, learning new skills, reading regularly, varying activities, and realistic expectations. Brain exercise. Evidence mixed. Enjoyable. Probably helps some.

questions.question: Stress-Management
questions.answer: Managing stress protects brain health. Treatment includes identifying stressors, relaxation techniques, exercise, adequate sleep, therapy if needed, and lifestyle changes. Chronic stress damages brain. Multiple management approaches. Essential for health.

questions.question: Smoking-Cessation
questions.answer: Quitting smoking reduces stroke and dementia risk. Treatment includes nicotine replacement, medications like bupropion, counseling, support groups, and multiple attempts often needed. Major brain health benefit. Never too late. Multiple resources available.

questions.question: Alcohol-Moderation
questions.answer: Limiting alcohol protects brain health. Treatment includes staying within guidelines, abstinence if problematic, treating addiction, support groups, and recognizing risks. Excessive alcohol damages brain. Moderation important. Addiction needs treatment.

questions.question: Blood-Pressure
questions.answer: Controlling blood pressure prevents stroke and dementia. Treatment includes medications, diet changes, exercise, weight loss, limiting salt, and regular monitoring. Major risk factor. Treatable. Prevents disability. Regular checking important.

questions.question: Cholesterol
